description:
All divey and when we went decked out in Halloween decor. Perfect for a late October pub crawl!

Where the drinks anything special to write home about? No. Was the beer selection that amazing? No. But the whole experience was fun everyone was super laid-back, if not a little grungy. But I totally dig that. It was fun, it was probably the best night we had in San Francisco. I would certainly go back but if you're going to go. Maybe make it one of the last stops in your pub crawl, so that you're a little more loosened up and can enjoy it for what it is. That's a fun little divey bar.
author: Adam H.

description:
I was heading out to a concert at the Oracle Arena and wanted to get a quick drink before catching the bart. Phone Booth is located within 4 minutes walking distance from the 24th Street Bart Station and they serve great drinks for super cheap!

I ordered a Greyhound and IPA for a total of only $10. Such a steal, especially here in SF! The only downside is that this place takes cash, which is why the drinks are inexpensive. 

If you're looking for a casual hangout spot to start your barhopping adventures in the Mission, then I highly recommend trying out Phone Booth! I will definitely will be coming here more before my concerts. :)
author: MyTien P.

description:
This place is a dive.  It definitely has that dive smell.  When you catch a whiff you will know what I mean.  That isn't necessarily a bad thing.  

It's definitely got character.  It's an easy night out, no frills just drink.  Drink and hang out and sit back and be yourself.
author: Pauline M.

description: It's a dive bar so don't expect frosted glasses or even bar stools that match much less look like they are from a design within reach catalogue. Still it's got a great jukebox and the staff is friendly and cool.
author: elizabeth m.

description:
CASH ONLY and DOG-FRIENDLY!!! 

The place itself is very small: around 4-5 small tables + bar sittings + a pool table.

$7-8 draft beers, not too bad prices. The selection of drinks is great. It seems like people of all ages go here, it has an interesting vibe. Everyone is very nice and friendly to each other here. It's definitely a place if you wanna stop by and pregame or just chill with friends for a bit. It is not particular clean or fancy, but then again it's not a place that you would stay for hours anyways. 

There was only 1 bartender when I and my friend went at 8pm on a saturday night but she knew what she was doing so we didnt have to wait for very long for our drinks. 
I would definitely dive in again in the future.
author: Veronica N.

description:
Hello,

I wanted to reach out about the events that transpired at your bar on Saturday night. Given the circumstances ended with me, you should probably hear from me. I know you've heard from many people... I have many dear friends that are much braver - but my voice should be heard, too.

On Saturday, I wanted to celebrate my boyfriends birthday at a bar we all love, and frequent often. To note, the minute we walked in, your door guy was aggressive. He walked around shoving chairs, clearing tables at unnecessary moments, and even giving myself weird looks. It was odd, and I noted this to myself, but didn't say anything out loud.

I wasn't outside when he started yelling at my friend that she "elbowed him", but given the three people that were are all my dearest friends, I know they tell the truth when they say that she didn't ever elbow him. Even as he was yelling at her, she remained calm, while he continued to insult them. I came outside as he was telling my friends "to go back where they came from", and calling them "entitled children." I was there for those comments.

By this point, he should have gone back to his chair. If he was correct, he should have been resolute with kicking my friend out of the bar and going back to do his job. But he was not.

As he continued to make inconsiderate and offensive remarks, he chose to zero in on another one my friends, who inquired about what happened. The door guy then  chose to show him by elbowing him in the side. Totally unprofessional, not cool and unnecessary. Obviously upsetting him, my friend asked him not to touch him. He then chose to zero in on him and began pushing him away from the front door, noting that he was "too close to the fucking door to be smoking there." It was unnecessary, and an indicator that he just wanted to fight. He continued to push him, and aggravate my friend. It was shocking. 

That was when I had enough. That is when I told him, that we would all be leaving, but if anyone should have been acting level headed in that situation, it should have been him. Because, out of all of us there -- he was the one working. He was currently at his "job", and instead of yelling at us, pushing people around, he should be acting like an adult. There were many others ways he could handled the situation, and this was not okay.

That is when he said, "Oh I'm sorry, what do you want me to say? "Yessa Massa?". 

Racism is something that I'm very used to, and aware of. I'm from Utah, where my black skin has been the base for many jokes. Why I haven't received jobs. Why I wasn't chosen to participate on teams, or just plain ignorance out in the world. But since moving to San Francisco 3 years ago, I've never had anything like this happen. I couldn't even speak. And even today, I'm still in shock that someone would outright and blatantly be so racist, ignorant, and just a sad human being. 

I understand that the management there was just doing their job last night, by asking us to leave. They didn't know the full story, they weren't outside to hear the  conversations or see the pushing. Their job is to protect their employees -- particularly in a workplace where patrons can get crazy. But now that you have the full story, I hope you make the right decision and choose to terminate his employment. Phonebooth deserves to be represented better -- and I know this because this is a bar that I frequent often. 

And in todays landscape, I think it would speak volumes if you let him continue on. He will continue to spew racist hate and intolerance, which I hope you have a no-tolerance policy for. 

Sincerely,
Shaquille Heath
author: Shaquille H.

description: One my alternative post work haunts if I get off before Mission Bar opens. (again, don't tell my sponsor, hah) Decidedly more hip than Mission Bar, I still enjoy the divey feel and that black cougar painting really is awesome. All the bartenders have been cool, the two guys I mostly see always remember I get a whiskey double. This place works for me both for my solo day time drink and a place I would go out with others at night, which is ideal for me!
author: Tanya T.

description:
This is a rad dive bar with quirky details, a friendly bartender and his equally friendly dog.  I came here at an off time and there was plenty of seating available, but I imagine this bar is not often packed.  

A dark and stormy was $7, as were quite a few of their beers.  Heavy handed pours, cold beers on tap (including green flash), and whatever well drinks you could imagine.  The bartender is super friendly, service is fast, and everyone in the bar is relaxed.  Plus, there's a pool table!

The chandeliers made of naked barbie dolls, and there are branches hanging from the ceilings.  It's located on a street corner, easy to find, and near bart.  They don't serve food, but we brought our food over from la taqueria around the corner and nobody seemed to mind.  Would definitely come back here if I was in the area!
author: Kenna H.

description: Double fuck it. I went from loving this place to not even stepping foot in it. I no longer wish to be discriminated against, smell like cigarette smoke or put up with the clueless crowd that frequents this spot.
author: Anabelle B.

description: This place has great energy...one of my fave local neighborhood spots to hang with a friend or solo.
author: Jason V.

description: The Phone Booth is a quaint dive bar in the mission. No crazy night is going to happen here, but it's a good place to start, come to with friends and have a conversation, or to play a game of pool. They have good mixed drinks, a small selection of beers too. Staff is nice and the place is well decorated. Don't expect too much of this bar, but it's a fun place to stop by
author: Ross S.

description: I hit up this spot for two reasons: (1) it's close to where I live; and (2) to chill with my main man Matt. Always greets me with a smile and good cheer! One of the gems of the Mission.
author: Jay D.

description: My favorite bar in SF. Dimmed light atmosphere. Last spot where locals meet before tech guys push them away.
author: Kendall M.

description: The diving dive of dives...but I absolutely love it. Now that it is Halloween season, the decor is kick ass. A great place for pregaming, a daring place if you want the beer and shot combo
author: Joe D.

description:
The inside of the place is as depressing as it looks on the outside :)

Overall, this place is like any other dive bar in the Mission, except it's actually slightly on the smaller side, with not a lot of space. There were signed photos of Barry Manilow and Tom Selleck on the wall, so presumably they were once patrons? In any case it's clear they no longer visit, because I have a hard time imagine them going there!

In any case, the beer was cheap (it was $5 Stella in the afternoon), and not a lot of patrons, so the bartender was kind of bored, which is reasonable.

Overall, an OK place for a quick drink if you happen to pass by, but probably not worth the extra detour to intentionally find this place.
author: Henry L.

description: My new favorite plaaaaaace. Bartender was a sweetheart, the dogs are plentiful, great local-dive feels and good strong drinks.  No hipsters on this Tuesday night!  One girl came in with her yoga pants but ended up leaving before she got a drink.  I guess there weren't enough Edison bulbs, subway tiles or expensive sriracha flavored bar snacks for her..? Phonebooth, I'll be back!
author: Adrian C.

description: Red felt pool table. Lots of dogs. Nice mix of gay, lesbian, and straight. Signed Tom Selleck photo.
author: Patrick S.

description: Great NYE fun.  They should do a DJ set at least once a month, music was good and kept us dancing all night. It actually felt like the Mission I love.  Strong drinks and no fuss. Chris Orr was the DJ, played rare gems all night, what a fucking party.
author: Robert M.

description:
Perfect for solo drinking. 

It's actually remarkable how much action they've managed to cram into their small footprint. Bench seating, a pool table, and a rock-solid jukebox are the highlights. Plenty of options on tap, and the cocktails are well done. Their one flaw is a tragic one: it's very popular. When this bar gets busy it's sweatier than MUNI.

No kitchen, but you can BYO eats. Cash only. No smoking anymore.
author: Vivek S.

description: I stoped by on Saturday night to get a drink with my girlfriend. The guard posted at the door I believe his name was Mark or Matt I cannot remember but he was awesome. He greeted us with a smile and welcomed us to the phone booth. He actually took the time to wish my girlfriend a Happy Birthday. We have gone to two places prior to that and no guard had acknowledge my girlfriends birthday until we met Mark or Matt. We went their had a few drinks and while I went in and out of the bar to smoke I had a conversation with the guard. He was very outgoing, smiling and provided excellent customer service. I give him credit for what this man has to deal with. There had been a bunch of people disrespecting him and he handle himself very well just by talking not even putting hands on people. I also witness this poor man get spit on and a cigar thrown at him. God bless you Mark or Matty on what you have to deal with. Thank you for being such a gentlemen and sorry you have to deal with a bunch of entitled rich kids. Hope to see you soon!
author: Jimmy P.

description: This bar just feels off. It seems a bit of a pretentious for a divy bar. It just felt off and I was too drunk to really care when I felt that. It like most of the neighborhood feels like its in between a dive and a bourgie bar. Like its transitioning and it needs to go one way or the other.
author: Thomas J.

description: Love this place. Nice people, a pool table, and dogs everywhere. It's the perfect neighborhood dive bar. It's usually possible to find a seat too.
author: Henry D.

description:
Came here for a dink, while out on a Saturday afternoon.  I had a bloody mary and my wife had a screw driver.  My bloody was a bit on the bland side, though a little salt helped.  The bartender was making it from scratch instead of using a pre-made mix.  When made from scratch I find it's a toss up, either it's amazing or lacking.  I probably would not order another bloody, but the screw driver was well mixed and there prices are reasonable. 

Divey yes, but I like the chill laid back vibe.
author: Nick G.

description:
It looks really intimidating from the outside, but it is actually a friendly place! Cozy, relatively affordable, Christmas lights, pool table. Better for small groups. 

I also came here for New Years Eve and it was a blast. Awesome decorations.
author: Mila K.

description: the most Berlin-lke Dive Bar I visited on the west coast yet. friendly people all aroung even if it looks a but intimidating at first sight. loved it.
author: Christian I.

description:
The only thing I really liked about this bar was probably the cheap beers. 

Other than that, it wasn't really my kind of crowd. There was a bunch of hipsters..not that there's anything wrong with that, but I was totally out of place with the plaid shirts, thick rimmed glasses, and beards. If you like that kind of stuff, then this is your place! Not to mention all the white boy music playing. (I'm not hating, I like white boy music. Lol) but like others have mentioned..it does kind of smell funky in here...
author: Yannie S.

description: No frill dive bar! Love the neighborhood vibe! Pools games are fun and people are friendly. Keep it open!
author: Xiu L.

description: Great bar! Great bartenders & a solid selection in the jukebox. I'd love to get back sometime when I'm back in the bay area. This place stands out as a fond memory of my 2nd trip to San Francisco.
author: J D.

description: Good bar to just chill and relax at. Good place to catch up with people and the music selection is pretty darn good. There's a pool table in the back and plenty of seats. Very divey bar for sure, but a nice bar. Would return.
author: Julie L.

description:
Had an amazing time here! Great atmosphere, and I'm pretty sure they free pour, so be careful when counting your drinks. You might have had a bit more than you thought! 
Service was prompt and the music was not trendy but/and certainly entertaining! 
Would come back in a heart beat!
author: Marta B.

description: Best donut salad in town. Ask for Tika!
author: Joshua Y.

description: Super chill dive bar equipped with a juke box, pool table, reasonable selection of drinks, and a friendly bartender. I will go back if I'm ever in the area again!
author: Umeet S.

description:
I think I just created this profile because of this place...

I belong to one of the rare breeds of Europeans that seldom get lost so far out in the world to make a living (yup, kinda like hobbits).
After a whole afternoon of pre-gaming (and a good portion of the night) we decided that the living room was rotating enough for us to leave. We stumbled to the computer and tried to find something that made us feel back home (a place where drunk smoking wasn't something to frown upon, the guy at the door smiled, and where you could get drunker without feeling guilty about the money spent in a party for you head, and that had a nearby alley for emergencies). The jukebox had a nice selection of music (but I think that an ipod was playing at the time-I don't remember if the jukebox had decemberists in it).

It totally hit the spot.


sorry for the crappy english
Tugas, este é o sítio!
author: Bea L.

description:
Second stop of our pub crawl for the birthday boy. Such a cool dive! Drinks were made with care and precision.

The chandelier with barbie dolls are not to be missed!
author: Yuchi C.

description:
If you don't like this bar...

We can't be friends, because it is awesome. 

Cheap and smoky and awesome.
author: Emily D.

description:
Shithole full of hipster douchebags sporting wallet chains, bad tattoos, Jason Mraz hats, and.. Well do you really need to know anymore to stay the hell away. Yes, I know hipster dochebag is redundant... but still worth of mentioning...

Oh, they also let patrons smoke in the bar, ensuring you will smell like ass from the combination of stale beer, sweaty ass, and smoke. Yuck
author: Jim B.

description:
We ended up in this bar mostly because nothing else around the area was open...Being from out of town we had no idea where else to go, and the decor/ambiance seemed cool at this place.

The people in the bar (clients) were nice and we even had an interesting conversation with a lovely local couple. Even the doorman was friendly.

But, as other people have mentioned, service at the bar was poor. This bartender guy seemed really annoyed at everything...rolling eyes, not smiling, etc.

I asked him for an Old Fashioned cocktail and he just rolled his eyes and said he didn't know what that was...(I mean, reaallly?)... 

He could have said that he could not make it cause e.g. he had no orange peel, or wtv... But he was just like: "I have no idea what you are talking about *rolls eyes*"

After explaining the idea, he finally made me a Manhattan that tasted a too much like pure alcohol. We still gave him a tip, hoping we would get a better attitude for the next round. But there was no next round...

My husband had a pint of beer... Nothing to mention on this, cause I guess you can't really miss that one, right?

Hopefully not all bartenders are like this one overly annoyed guy, cause the place was pretty cool... But then again, I think reviews have to be honest!
author: Sonia O.

description:
Dive bar with decently priced drinks, awesome music and no pretentious (insert word here). 

Love that it is a stone's throw away from work, so I have a feeling that I may become a regular.

Finally, a place to decompress after a long day in the Mission!!
author: Hilda Z.

description:
I dig this place because of one specific reason: You can smoke inside and no one is going to say anything! 

The bartenders are attentive, the jukebox is always jamming, the pool table hosts intense games, and everyone is just having a damn good time. 

The craziest thing I saw here was a dog-napping. I kid you not, some guy brought his dog, and another dude just unleashed the dog, grabbed it and walked off. The dog owner was so drunk he thought his dog was still on the leash. Woah!
author: Maggie K.

description:
Awesome! 

We took a cab to the Mission area and were lost in a sea of taco stands and shops. We hit mobile Yelp and walked a block over to this place. 

We were a bit apprehensive to go in initially. It was dark, a bit dingy, and looked like a locals only bar. We each took a gulp of air and headed in. 

What the....They are playing Morrissey on the Jukebox and have a picture of Tom Select (Magnum years) on the wall. The guy I was with asked if Morrissey was like the Cure and...oddly enough tada they were playing The Cure as he was asking. 

Every fear fell off and we got to drinking. I opted for the 7 dollar PBR and Shot of Whiskey special. No mystery it was PBR but must have been popular because it was fresh PBR. I think there is a difference as you are drinking but the next day is the same. 

The bartender and people at the bar were very friendly and as soon as we left I wanted to come back.
author: Chris M.

description:
Cute little dive and I did like the remnants of the Halloween decorations mixing with all the other random stuff. Bullfighting painting + goblin lady + black claw branches: yesss

Showed up right when Glee started, so conversations all kinda ground to a halt and even the bartenderess stopped mid-pour to watch. Typical Mission crowd, with somehow a heavier lean on the gay lever. Cheapish drinks.

Docked 'em one star for the heavy ciggy smoke. Love the place, but I can't stand it when my clothes are imbued with smokiness for the next few days.
author: Kevin L.

description:
Ring... ring...

"Who is it?"

"Hey, playah!  It's Age-Inappropriate Drinking.  I've conferenced in Poor Decision Making."

"Hi guys!  I didn't think I'd hear from you til the weekend."

"Oh, wow.  Now we're just your *weekend* friends?  Nice.  ANYWAY, we're calling from The Phone Booth.  Come meet us for some rambling conversations, a little light brain cell loss and a shorter life span!"

"Yeah.  Listen guys, you know, I'm married now, and I feel like it's time for me to hang out more with my couple friends.  You know, Gardening and Baking.  They're actually really cool once you get to know them.  Reading and PBS Documentaries are great, too.  I mean, they put me to sleep sometimes, but..."

"Jesus!  We hate them!  And can we remind you that there used to be a time when you wouldn't be caught DEAD with them?  Sometimes we don't even know who you are anymore....  Plus, you know who's here?" 

"Who?"

"Only your ex."

"Noooo.  Seriously?  Nick O'Teen?  I thought he was 86ed from like everywhere.  I mean, he's not even allowed to hang out in front of *restaurants* anymore.  Everyone hates him."

"Oh no, girl.  He's here.  At the tables."

"God, I feel like we're toxic together.  But it couldn't hurt to say hi...  I mean, it's not like I'm going to DO anything...  Things between us always get hazy and leave a bad taste in my mouth, but I've moved on now...  I'm sure this time will be different..."

"Uh-huuuuuuuh...."  

"See you in five minutes!"
author: Rosie W.

description:
The Phone Booth is one of those dive bars that gets it just right. On the corner, very dim lighting, nice little pool table, decent selection of liquor, and the best jukebox in SF. It's not an intimidating spot and the bartenders are quite friendly. If you want a great local spot that isn't packed to the brim and serving drinks made by "mixologists" then this is the spot.

Dog friendly, cool people, and just an all around great bar :)
author: Nick E.

description:
So far it's my favorite (session) bar in the Mission. Fairly affordable cocktails and beers, but that's not what really sold me... it was the jukebox that did! What a great selection. Being able to put on "Enjoy the Silence" and have people from every corner of the bar either hum or sing along, that was kinda cool. :) And despite that there wasn't really any dancing, and that's kind of my thing. I'm an old man at heart.

Oh yeah, and before I forget that this is a bar in the Mission: PBR pint and Jameson shot (almost like a 1.5shot) is $7. Not bad if you're taking the midnight express train to inebriation station.

Pool table was kind of crowded and I couldn't "get next" on it, but maybe next time. Not to mention the free popcorn is a plus - reminded me strongly of the Graduate in Oakland. I'd love to come back.

I heard that one of my friends got some attitude from the barkeep when trying to order a complicated drink, so it's not perfect. But I like it.
author: Josh K.

description: Classic dive bar and I like it.
author: Sarah S.

description: A true dive. Way nicer inside than the outside. This place makes a mean cosmo according to some sources. The bartender is requisitely rude.
author: Andrew K.

description: Must be a popular place , place was packed , every table , and stool was taken , looked like a "hipster" place , people seemed nice , didn't stay for ping because of how packed it was
author: Anthony M.

description: The bartender needs to stop being a gruff, standoffish wanker. Details need to be updated as smoking is not allowed here. Won't be returning
author: Luke C.

description: Was looking it a few cheap beers on an early afternoon. Perfect spot. $2 pbr and someone brought their dogs. Bartender was talking to regulars about local politics. 2pm friday feb 13th
author: Colin H.

description: Service is so crappy. Not sure if the fact we weren't locals pissed off the bartender or if it was because we wanted more then one drink. We were staying in an apartment across the street and wanted to grab a few drinks after dinner. This guy was beyond annoyed about EVERYTHING, we felt super unwanted and had to flag him down to order another cocktail (there were 10 people at the bar). Service sucks!
author: Emily W.

description:
My rating would've been higher, but the fat, bald queen with the attitude,  that was working at the bar, brought my ratings down a lot.  Cheap drinks. low key.  Needs a better selection at the jukebox.

Note to Queens, Hipsters, Etc.-  A mean, snobby attitude does not make you superior to me or make you look cool, it makes you a delusional douche.
author: Tate B.

description:
Bartender, I hope you tell everyone else the same thing you told us about Popcorn at public establishment's..LOL! BTW..you are cute! 

Cheap, strong drinks, dark, mix bag of people and good music. Just what the doctor ordered. Or  would that be the devil?
author: Ennos P.

description:
I was a little hesitant about this dive, but I finally got a chance to check it out.

I had a great time, drinks are cheap, you can smoke (not at the bar), and play pool!
author: Mario M.

description:
"Woo hoo, as good as it gets" indeed.

Blowing all my money on filipino bbq and a scoop of Olive Oil and Secret Breakfast at neighboring Humprey Slocumb, drinking did not seem like a good idea--fiscally. 

It looks like a residence outside, the only distinct characteristic is a humble sized sign: Phone Booth. It was hard to spot and definitely had a hole in the wall feel to it when entering because the only lights are candlelight, blue christmas lights and red lights,meaning it's almost complete darkness! I felt like I was at a pub in 'Diagon Alley [only Harry Potter fans know] and noticed it was reminiscent of Broken Record by Geneva & Mission. 

The alcohol comes in cheap and generous amounts, God bless them. 
I ordered a shot of patron, salt rim and sprite back. I gathered the last of my ones and paid up, expecting about 1/4 of the shot glass to be full (like normal bars in San Francisco) but to my glee (or perhaps horror) the alcohol was kissing the rim of the glass, almost overflowing, the sprite back was a normal sized $3.50 soft drink at a restaurant. I was in heaven and in drunk stupor in no time.  I forgot to mention they clearly gave me a double, it wasn't in those trendy small shot glasses with the heavy bottom but a scotch on the rocks glass filled to the top! the top! the top! weee

Same can be said of my friends drink orders

If I could describe the atmosphere further, I would advise you picture a hookah bar on Haight street, except smaller and with a pool table, no baklava ;) Attire is casual, parking abundant. 


hope this helps xoxoxox =)
author: Olivia Vanessa R.

description:
You can smoke inside, but I don't smoke anymore.

Their drinks are strong and cheap, but it's cash only.

It's within walking distance of Amanda's apartment, but for the first 5 minutes, we weren't even sure there was a bartender on duty.

They have a pool table, but I'm sure if I asked to play they'd tell me to fuck right off.

Soooo...3 stars.
author: Jaime L.

description:
The Phone Booth is the only bar in SF where I was called out for what I was wearing. The sooooo ironic hipster bartender refused to acknowledge me because I was sporting a gray brooks brother polo shirt and pressed chinos. Sorry man, but I didn't get the memo. I didn't know knee socks and tattered t-shirt was the preferred dress-code. Will you serve me a drink anyway? Douchebag.

Listen hipster, one day you are going to have to grow up and get a real job with real responsibilities. Your days of skateboarding on South Van Ness won't be so COOL anymore.

In retrospect, I really shouldn't be writing this review because I live about 10 feet from here. I can already hear the sound of chuck taylors making their way to my door. Hipsters are like zombies. They congregate in small packs and once you kill them; there are a hundred more ready to impress you with their precious "irony". If the city ever puts all the hipsters on their own island, it would be filled with establishments like Phone Booth and Boogaloos.

God, I'm such an a-hole when it comes to these people. I hope you burn down, just like "Benders" did. 1 star.
author: John T.

description:
hole in the wall, hipster heaven.
nice & funny servers
normal beer prices.
author: Katrina M.

description:
If it's granted that bars are worthy of the same innate consideration as most citizens (if not more so, since most citizens don't exist solely to help me get drunk), then a bar is innocent until proven guilty. Thus, every bar's rating begins with 5 perfect stars and goes down as all available evidence is held against it.

In the case of the Phone Booth, allow the prosecution to offer the follow exhibits:

Exhibit A: A cadre of too many smug, self-conscious hipster elitists (or, worse, those who desperately want to be hipsters but can't even pull off the act of fashionable conformity). It's a known fact that the Phone Booth is post-collegiate hipster central, which thus makes it a cornerstone of Mission district gentrification...not to mention more than a little annoying when you're surrounded by a swarm of horn-rimmed fake intellectuals. Penalty: Minus 1 star.

Exhibit B: Ironic decor. Not merely kitschy decor, since I can appreciate the whimsical flair of retro paintings and lamps, but the sort of all-out decorative absurdity only hipsters think is actually funny, e.g., a motherfuggin' New Kids on the Block poster. Get your own life and live it, ironic losers. Penalty: Minus 1 star.

Exhibit C: Subtle mood-lighting halogen lamps above the bar. Sorry, but no so-called "dive" should ever have these things. They reveal the latent yuppie aspirations of any bar (and/or citizen). If I wanted to sit under a chic string of crimson halogen bulbs, I'd go to some trendy SoMa cocktail lounge with a name like "Lotion" or "Smooth" --- and then I'd kill myself, because I hate those kinds of places. Penalty: Minus 1 star.

As all-encompassing prosector, judge, jury, and executioner, however, I will go easy on the Phone Booth because of several extenuating circumstances, including:

- relatively cheap prices (i.e., $2.25 pints of PBR, $3.75 tall boys of Tecate, etc.)

- a pretty-sweet chandelier made of Barbie torsos

- a very solid jukebox with punk, post-punk, country, funk, indie rock, and a blessed minimum of cliched Greatest Hits CDs

- a generally enjoyable combination of cozy size, comfortable darkness, and casual bartenders.

So I give the Phone Booth back 1 of its penalty stars, leaving a total of 3 stars overall. Take down the NKOTB poster and I may give it 4. I'm permanently withholding the 5th star until one of the resident hipsters can finally explain to me why the hell I should give a crap about Stephen Malkmus.
author: John G.

description:
The name is the size. It's a fun joint to hang at deep in the heart of the mission, pool table, free popcorn, decorated during Halloween, good enough beer. 

Playing pool can be a butt sometimes as it's so packed your cue can hit the wall. Not a lot of seating, be prepared to haggle for a chair if you have  a group, but it gets the job done and can be a fun start to a mission pub crawl.
author: Kelly S.

description: So tragic what has happened to this place. It was once really awesome, then kinda awesome, and now it's an imperious hipster pad. Putting paper in the ashcan? Yeah, good idea. Yelling at patrons, yeah, that's better. This has been a favorite for a long time (even when it was a gay bar!), but after being pushed out of the way and snidely remarked to by an unwelcoming bartender (I'm not hipster enough, I guess), this place is over. For people who can pay, anyway. Sad.
author: Vincent R.

description:
Something of a stank tank.  Phone Booth started off our recent mission/folsom bar crawl by being really, really weak. 

They have a decent selection of beer but so do most quality bars in SF. 

What I focused on more was how run down it is, a pool table so scratched it's barely functional (and crammed into such a tiny space you'll take 3/4 of your shots with the short stick), and a bunch of hipster lame asses.  This isn't the people friendly break you want from Castro or Russian Hill snobbery; it's mission snobbery with crappy music and no decor.  

And they need to do something about the smokers.  It's illegal and it's really gross and it's really rude and it's not fun.  

Next bar crawl will skip this place!
author: Luke M.

description:
If there were an outdoor patio it might get 5 stars but then it wouldn't really be the phonebooth.  Friendlier than other bars in the area.  Even if you don't drink it, it is comforting to know that there is $2 Pabst in pint glasses.  The history, as I've learned, is that it used to cater to gay workers in the Pac Bell building across the street.  There are still locals who show up and a pretty tolerant crowd most nights - tolerant of people of various ages, races, genders, sexualities and fashionabilities.  Still, it's the Mission, and clearly not a bar for the Latino immigrants in the neighborhood (though even a couple of them drop in for Tecate when it isn't too crowded), so it is often dominated by hipsters, their contemporaries and their admirers.

Despite the 4 stars, it is my bar of choice in the neighborhood and the city for that matter.
author: Carlos V.

description:
As far as I'm concerned, this is the perfect dive bar. It's small, it's dark, the drinks are strong (when you order a rum and Coke, you literally get mostly rum with a little Coke) and cheap ($4!), and they have pretty amazing decor -- there's a naked Barbie chandelier. What more do you want? We were there on a Saturday around 9, and it wasn't overly crowded. We were able to walk in and grab a seat. Getting a drink wasn't a problem either, as the bartender acknowledged you quickly once you approached the bar, and waited on you soon after. 

When you walk in, there's a bar to your right, and a church pew-like bench lining the left wall, along with tables and chairs. The decor -- and I'm not sure if this is just seasonal or what -- consisted of these awesome tree-like structures with faux cobwebs and skulls on them. Very Halloween-y. There's also an awesome jukebox, as tons of other reviewers have mentioned. Oh, and -- this is one of the cleanest dive bars I've ever been in! Definitely a plus. In fact, someone at another table fell out of his chair and shattered a glass of beer on the floor while we were there. They immediately picked up all the glass shards, and mopped the floor so that it was Pinesol-fresh. Not exactly a delightful scent, but a helluva lot better than garbage, and I appreciated that my shoes weren't sticking to the floor! I will most definitely be frequenting this fine establishment. 

P.S. It's cash only. Wah-wahhh. But there is an ATM on site if you want to pay the $3 fee.
author: Natahley B.

description:
Little hole in the wall full of mostly losers and a couple hipsters.  Gwen Stefani has been spotted here quite a few times when she is in the area.  I used to work in the area and always walk by the bar and look inside if it looked like any fun and it usually looked pretty lame.  

If you get drunk there it is better of course, what bar isn't?  I wouldn't bother with this bar.  Check it out if you want.  It will only cost you the price of a drink.
author: Cynthia B.

description:
Let's get this straight. You drive a Bimmer, you look like you just stepped off the set of Sex and the City, and your favorite companions are your cell phone headset and your credit card. YOU totally would HATE this place!!!

For the rest of this, this is a little spot of HEAVEN. Small, narrow, long, dark, and cozy, with charming vintage elements, like a great wood bar down the length of the place, plaster dancers on one wall, pool table, and cheezy/cool old paintings. Large selection of quality booze to choose from, too. 

After drinking one too many coffees over the day, I was hopelessly dehydrated (and working on a headache), so I started the evening off with a couple glasses of water, while my friend knocked back a few beers. The bartender was totally cool about it, was super nice, and kept voluntarily refilling my water. Once I was suitably watered, I ordered a Cosmo (the first of two)... not only was my Cosmo exceptionally tasty, it was inexpensive, and plentiful (the bartender gave me the extra drink from the shaker in a second glass--- what my friend called the "Junior" cocktail). He even chilled the martini glass with ice water before pouring my drink. Lots of class.

From my vantage point, at the corner of the bar, looking down the length of the bar, I had the perfect people watching space, watching the influx of interestingly diverse, unpretentious locals and cute dogs at the door. The place was super chill at 9 pm, and got much more popular in the next few hours. The great thing is, the music was fun, but not so loud up you couldn't have a low-key conversation at the bar. Sitting at the tables would be better for folks who like to get up close and personal with their neighbors, and aren't too claustrophobic. 

A good place to go with a friend (or two), a date, or alone, since people seemed happy to chat with newcomers. Dive into this place as quick as you can!!!

(Sidenote: Best of all, not once during the night did I feel too old.)
author: Paula W.

description: Let me phone all my smoker friends because Phone Booth is probably one of the last standing bars you can actually smoke at. Even though I'm a "quit-except-when-I-sometimes-drink" smoker, I could even find value in a place like this. Divey place with super affordable drinks and heavy on the pour for the poor. What's not to like about this place? The Mission impossible secretly possible.
author: Celia C.

description:
The more time I spent in the bar, the more I enjoyed the ambiance.  I like my bars like I like my coffee: strong, dark and proud.  This place certainly hit all three.

Some additional comments:

-Hoegaarden on draft for 4 dollars.  Yes, I said 4 dollars.
-Sweet lighting: I want to there were a few branches covered in blue and green lights hanging from the ceiling
-It's called Phone Booth.  Like if we went inside, then we might turn into superheroes.
author: Jeremy G.

description: This place sucks. The patrons smoke inside the bar and the bartender only meekly once mentioned to one person that they should take their cigarette outside...which the person ignored. Don't go here unless you want your clothes and hair to stink like an ashtray and you really like cancer. Get a drink just about ANYWHERE else in the Mission.
author: J.J. P.

description:
Pretty fun little dive bar. Decently priced drinks, good music. And you can smoke inside!! I know that's a big deterrent for those who don't smoke, but big plus for those who do. 
Overall good time
author: Caitlin S.

description:
The Phone Booth was sweet relief from the hell that was Zeitgeist earlier that evening. An in-offensive cool bar with great juke box, I think I rinsed all my dollars on that machine that night. Really great bartender, friendly and chatty and really great atmosphere inside
My only complaint was the massive peephole in the girls toilet door!
author: Charlotte H.

description:
The Phone Booth is a great spot.

Chris the handsome French bartender can make a fabulous bloody Mary.

Need I say more?
author: Cara L.

description:
The Phone Booth is named that because of the Phone Company across the steet. Atone time it was THE hang out for company employees, especially gays ones.
 I have been going there for 32 yers and have seen a lot of changes.  The smoking is supposed to be after 7PM, BTW.
 Essentially, it is a mixed bar, but was Gay for a very long time. 
 It is no pize for  deor but it is friendly. An eclectic mix of bartenders. My personal favourites are Martin and Christopher.  I do not normally go in on the other's shifts.
author: Randall M.

description:
Terribly unassuming, but I dig it. 

This seems like one of those "neighborhood bars" where it's all the same crew all the time, but manages to feel and be so unpretentious. The drink selection is good and the bartender (Martin) is attentive. Bathrooms are kind of weird though. But you can smoke, I am told there is popcorn, and the lighting is nice and low (but not Ruby Room-low). 

Also, pool table! I'm typically not down with playing pool at new bars where I don't know anyone, but the vibe here was so chill that I really enjoyed myself and developed a more-than-pleasant repertoire with everyone I played against.
author: Natalye R.

description: Best jukebox ever! Good crowd, good prices. The bartenders don't really like me but that's their right cause I'm an idiot.
author: Sandy V.

description:
Monday February 17th 1 am. my Money was stolen prior and i had three dollars to my name. I walked into the phone booth and asked the bartender for a PBR which was priced at three dollars even. I gave her my money and she began to curse at me for not having enough for a tip. Understanding to my best ability, i tried explaining that i would tip her the dollar if my money wasn't stolen. She responded with "im not even fucking listening." 
It was as hilarious as it was kind of sad someone would curse at a person who paid full price for the beer but couldnt afford tip that night under circumstance. so i left the PBR without taking a sip and told her to keep the three dollars so she'd calm down. She continued to curse at me as i walked out of the door.
I cant honestly say the place itself is bad, however that particular situation was completely uncalled for as it was entirely immature. little did she know i write for a local paper and am still contemplating on whether i decide to let the situation slide, or proceed in writing a very, very bad review.
author: Phillip W.

description:
A fun little bar.

I enjoyed sitting by the door and people watching while enjoying a pint of beer with my friends. There is a pool table, free popcorn, and a lot of crazy crap on the walls... seriously! The beer selection could use some work. Oh and the bartender let me charge my phone. That was nice of him!
author: Eric G.

description:
Dark, dank, typical SF dive bar (not a bad thing in and of itself).
Cash only.

Two stars because the ultra-hipster crowd was rather obnoxious and uninteresting, and because it's filled with people smoking.
author: Jen R.

description:
This place is dingy on the outside, hipster-chic on the inside: an allegory of the typical clientele.  It's got great ambiance, the drinks are reasonable, and there's a pool table.  Add some dancing and this could be a favorite-bar contender.  

Though there is no dancing, there is in-house entertainment... i.e. the 21-year-old hipster kids who managed to get themselves kicked out (to the great delight of everyone else).  Dingy inside and out.  Sit down and let Auntie Mari tell you all about it.

Once upon a time there was a group of very pleasant people who were trying to enjoy their $6 shot-of-Cazador-and-Tecate combos at a bar called Phone Booth.  But during their game of billiards in the very cramped back of the bar, these dingy kids kept:
- getting in your face while you were trying to shoot
- intentionally standing behind you, blocking your cue
- making out on the pool table (WTF?)
- placing drinks on the table while trying to impregnate one another

it was this last bullet point which eventually did them in.  You see, the bartenders are very sensitive about the protection of the table, which is indeed very nice.  when one BT tapped a girl on her shoulder to ask her to remove it, 
SMACK! SHE SLAPPED HIM ON HIS FACE. JUST LIKE THAT.

Then there was a bunch of noise and chaos and suddenly our pool game was very pleasant again.  hoorah!  

good show, good show.
author: Mari C.

description: Cool dive bar except that a lot of people smoke inside even though there are No Smoking signs inside.
author: Dan R.

description: me and a few friends went bar hopping and we stumbled upon this gem. We wnet in and to our surprise people were actually smoking inside the bar, which I'm totally down with since i smoke myself. The jukebox had great selections of songs and the drink price were pretty cheap compared to other places we went to. Will come here again. i love the environment and the people.
author: Alex R.

description: Smokey smoke... for sure. Good place to bring your nicotine addicted buds, but bad place if you're trying to quit. Cheap drinks, typical dive, cute red telephone booths painted on the doors. Pool table in the back, table seating on the side. Bathrooms... really strange. The doors have windows on them, (high enough not to see anything too crazy, but weird to think someone's watching you- its like your in a lab getting observed...) I could just see someone far too drunk pushing open the doors- since conveniently they don't lock. Guess it cracks down on the hotboxing or lovemaking, but honestly don't think they'd care anyways.
author: Naomi K.

description: IMO one of the quintessential dive bars in the Mission. A great mix of people, including a bunch of foreigners (who come I believe because of the ability to smoke inside--just not while sitting at the bar!) Big fan of the lighting and the energy here. Always some weird stuff hanging from the ceiling. The crowd is a good mix of gay/queer, hipster, young and old. Seems every time I go I end up having a conversation with somebody truly interesting. So. Oh and a big plus is the reasonable cost of beer. $2.50/pint for Pabst, $4 for quality brews like Lagunitas and Sierra Nevada. Juke box is all right, there's a pool table but good luck playing. Bathrooms are gross but who really cares? It's a dive, and a good one at that.
author: Jimmie M.

description:
I love this place!!! awesome bartenters.cheap drinks,good tunes on the juke box...a barbi doll chandalier...what else can you ask for...oh and free pop corn. And a pool table.
 one of the few places where everyone is welcomed...straight,gay,bi,transgendered...I have seen them all there having a great time. I am a fan
author: Raul A.

description:
I always have a good time here, except for the fact that my eyes start stinging from all the cigarette smoke.

The have a pool table in the back and a juke box and lots of small tables. The crowd is usually pretty fun and I've always met at least a few cool people here. 

It's a dive bar and it's chill. I'm a fan.
author: Jackie G.

description: You know those bars you go to where it's obvious their staff hates everyone? At some places it's endearing, but this is not one of those. If you like dive bars with a crusty staff, Phone Booth might be your new watering hole. Not for me though... after having an unpleasant experience ordering drinks on a slow Sunday, my friend and I chugged our beers and promptly left. I don't know what we did- we're nice! We're good tippers! We like dive bars & beer! For shame, Phone Booth.
author: K M.

description: I love this place. The prices are pretty reasonable and a good atmosphere. Everyone I met there was so friendly, they made me feel as though I was back in Texas.
author: Celine S.

description:
Back in the day when my friends drove me back home, I would always see this bar. I didn't know why it caught my eye... maybe because of the name? The location? I don't know... but for some reason, I kinda remembered it.

So when I was asked to meet up with someone for a first date to hang out at the Phone Booth, it sounded awfully familiar. When she explained where it was, a photo surged into my consciousness from my memory bank and I instantly knew what she was talking about.

I wasn't surprised to find a bunch of hipsters inside. They've taken over the Mission, y'know. But I didn't feel too out of place... just a tad bit uncomfortable and anxious... my default setting when I'm on a first date with someone I'm interested in.

They had whatever beer I wanted at the time... either Fat Tire or Anchor Steam or one of the well known Dutch beers... whatever it was, it was cheap, cold and great. 

To be honest, I had a great time there... of course, it was probably because of the company I was with. But then, to put it subtly (only because I know about the ban and I didn't want to get anyone in trouble,) it became like a European bar... in the worst way possible. But fuck, if people are going to point it out, I might as well... it got smoky in there. Of course it would... the hipsters started filling up the joint after all. And since I can't fucking stand cigarette smoke, it got a little uneasy in there. She wanted to leave, too, so we both left to avoid the smoke.

So overall, it's a great place if you're a smoking hipster and/or you love not paying a lot for beer. I'd go here again but I just can't stand cigarette smoke, so I probably won't. I would have gave it two stars because of the smoke, but honestly, that really is the only bad thing about it... and since I went on a Wednesday, it wasn't too crowded and I didn't feel overly agitated, like I do in most crowded bars. So that deserves a full star. I'm glad I didn't go on a weekend... I don't know how bad (or good) the rating would have been if I went here on a crowded Friday night.
author: Chris S.

description:
Ok, I think Phone Booth has surpassed El Rio as my fav spot for a bloody mary.   They too use Guiness and the oh-so tangy delish pickled green beans, but for the same price give or take a few pennies you can get top shelf vodka. (Note to self: run on sentence).  I was feeling a little sideways from the previous night's festivities and two of these babies set me right!

Pretty chill crowd and friendly bartenders, one lovely lass bought be a beer..thanks!

Def like this little hole in the wall. The only thing I question is why they allow people to smoke in there.  Otherwise, A-ok.
author: Faith S.

description:
An alcoholics paradise thanks to the bargain basement drink prices. One of the best not so divey dive bars in the city. Great uber hipoisie atmosphere, crowd and jukebox. Though there's some activity and decibels, it's not bad enough that you can't hold some convo. WARNING: This watering hole ain't for asthmatics...bring inhaler. Otherwise, prepare for the kind of lounge space that Charles Bukowski would feel right at home. It's mui metro!

4 thingys.
author: Johnny C.

description:
i can't count the times an amour will inevitably state "let's go to the phone booth".

oh no, not again.  OK, it will be fun, it always is.  you just wish that you didn't have a date once you're there.  ;)  

cash only please.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X_3bbEsELVo
author: Noel J.

description:
The Prince Hits CD here is busted. Wasted other peoples money last night trying to hear Sexy MF and another fine Prince song. Don't cocktease with the Prince please, even if it's not my money.

In line with that, if you're enjoying a happy hour here and a drunken regular asks you to pick out some songs on the jukie because he doesn't have good taste, know ye this : he'll want to know what every song you chose is and by whom and also what it's like (I just want to hear something fun! Upbeat!). Then moments later when the song comes up he'll want to know all that all over again. Which, whom, what and suchlike as if he wasn't even listening the first time. About the time Violent Femmes came on and he asked "Is this Prince?" I went to the Red Place of the semi-batshit musical academic. "Dude, this is like the opposite of Prince. Are you even listening?".

Props anyhow to the regulars here. This is one Mission bar that didn't alienate all the original joints rummies when the cool kids bought it. God bless their elastic pants, these lifers. Actual Gov't check recipients slurping down their E&Js before the fixed gear crowd checks in for their shift. You don't see that often. Nothing sadder then seeing a guy in a straw cowboy hat with a Saddam moustache staring longingly at the Latin-American or Doc's Clock as if to say, "Man, I used to get in some knife fights up in this. But no more." Makes me get all Indian Crying At Garbage.

Great bartenders. So good they'd almost rate Five Stars. But there's the thing about the Prince CD hustle. Do not deny me Prince. To that end, if a working Prince anthology is an important bar criteria to you, feel free to judge this review "useful".

Check The Update 01/14/07:
My whistle-blowing saw a clear result in Wanna Be Your Lover earlier tonight. I'm going back for happy hour tomorrow to see if I can break off some Let's Go Crazy. Dearly beloved, when Prince breaks down The Agent don't sleep!
author: Jeremy W.

description:
So I was sitting in the 21st Amendment drinking mediocre beer and the person I'm hanging out with says, "lets go to the phone booth, do you know where that is?" I'm a little surprised because she lives in North Beach and I didn't think anyone outside the Mission knew about this place. It's on the far side of the mission and not on the trendy side of Mission St. 

Not only do I know about it but also it's only a few blocks from my house. I wandered in there once and I got the feeling that it's a really clicky place and hadn't been back because while I liked it no one ever suggested going there.

The Phone booth is a cool little spot, it's small like the name suggests. There are plenty of colorful regulars, including a girl with elf ears. The beer is still only $4 a pint.  Also they didn't even seem to get mad when my companion kicked the table and knocked all the drinks on the floor breaking the glasses in the process. They sprung into action to clean it up like it happens there regularly.
author: Manny F.

description:
cheap drinks, rad service, creepy decorations, popcorn and a pool table.

i like coming to this place when i am in the neighborhood.
author: Carmel U.

description:
what is the deal with hipster and marina drama? people are people so why should it be, you and i should get along so awfully.
YOU LIVE IN SAN FRANCISCO. if you have a problem with

1. hipsters
2. bridge and tunnel and their kin
3. trust fund yuppies
4. crackheadz & transients
5. vegans
6. homo-sexuals (gasp)
7. normal people
8. tourists
9. time-travelling robots

then WTF are you doing here? dont go to mexico if you dont like mexicans. go back to suburbia aka purgatory aka where i came from

if you feel "not cool enough," tis' because YOU have issues with self-esteem.

take it from me, i speak from experience.

-THE MORE YOU KNOW-

yes this bar is small, the pool table is like catching a deluge in a paper cup. prodigious cigarette smoke permeates and the popular/mainstream-indie jukebox follows suit. stale pocorn. cheap drinks. surprisingly congenial bartenders. dudes with 10-o'clock shadows and members only jackets. girls drunk off their asses but not as easy pickins as your archetypal only 2 more vodka tonics away from a gangbang ho. 

1- booze cheap. that mean more horny drunk girls
2- smoke allow. me smoke. me like
3- hipster crowd. me wear tight pants. me fit in
4- jukebox. mainstream hits. better than no hits on jukebox.
5- popcorn. me no know what say about that.

BOTTOM LINE: ive gotten FCUKED up here many a time and its a great place to do it. worth the trek to the ass end of the mish
disclaimer - avoid if you have problems with SSS (smoking, scenesters, self-esteem)

edit: the jukebox! omg it has shiny toy guns AND arcade fire! 
that alone elevates the phone booth into the upper ring of good bars.
author: JT X.

description:
2 stars for ambiance.... staff was rude... even though i was the only patron. "Irish" bartender gave me a lecture on asking for 50 cents to complete my dollare three juke box request....after playing the only music on his box that he was jammin out to......
 lesson... DON'T GO ANYWHERE........just sayin
author: bryan h.

description:
Drinks. Strong drinks. Drinks that get the job done.. whatever that job may be. My friend took me here the other night after a long night of studying studying studying. A stiff drink was in order.

I love this place! Dim lighting, so even after a few drinks I still looked good ... well I thought so at least. Loves the juke box.
I won't lie I felt a little awkward since I don't smoke the ciggs but after 2 drinks I didn't mind. Blah blah hipster central - I met a nice boy named Gabe and he was rocking the shit out of that scarf and flannel shirt.
author: Amanda S.

description:
Though, once again, I refuse to qualify something as a dive that clearly is not, I do like this bar a lot.

I like it from the strong drinks to the very eerie Barbie doll chandelier hanging overhead to the great jukebox that gets regularly updated to the regulars that span from surly and strung out to tragically hip. 

This place is dark, sometimes crowded, sometimes blurry but always fun!
author: Drue C.

description:
Walking into the Phone Booth on a Friday night is like walking into a house party.  You get the feeling you're going to know these folks a whole lot better by the time the evening's over.

But unlike a house party, the Phone Booth never fails to deliver an entertaining cast of characters.  Wasted and chain smoking, they're looking for nothing but a good time. From jangle jammers to Joeffrey ballet dancers, they're all obliterated.

Go straight to the bar and order a few cheap ones.  Drink 'em down and stay until late night oblivion.
author: Nicole G.

description: As far as dives go, the place is a full five stars. Cheap. Eclectic crew of regulars, really well decorated for Halloween when I was there. Jukebox. Get a PBR and a Jameson for $7 any time. If you're down with indoor smoking, you've found your happy place.
author: Henry D.

description:
Yes, this place does suffer from an infestation of hipsters, but, umm, hello: this is San Francisco. Besides, the usefulness of the term hipster has faded every since Norman Mailer burped out the term one morning while sitting on the toilet, yelling at nothing in particular. But mostly I think this because I would likely be labeled a hipster by someone who didn't know me, and I hate to think that sort of socio-profiling is going on in this enlightened city.

So yes: if you enjoy 24 oz cans of Tecate and cheap whiskey, that doesn't necessarily make you a hipster; moreover, you will probably enjoy this place. And yes, you can smoke inside. You might have one of two reactions to that sentence: "Ewwwwwww" or "Hells to the fuck yes!" I happen to fall in the latter category, as it gets cold as bees outside, and sometimes you don't want to relinquish your precious seat just to go feed your little addiction, you know?

And I say "precious" because this place is small and does get crowded quickly, so show up early and lay claim to one of the tables in front. Then send out a trusted envoy from your party to buy drinks and mess with the jukebox, which is truly fucking amazing, if you are into that sort of thing.

Finally, there is a pool table here, but anyone serious about playing pool will find themselves hopelessly annoyed by the tiny space.

Basically, this is one of those bars that sucks if you can't find a seat, but rules if you can. My review is based on having a seat.
author: Max H.

description:
Like Clark Kent you enter the phone booth and you turn into Superman.
It happens to all the patrons too or they feel that way when they leave.

Inside the the spacious booth you'll find lots of booths a single bar and a pool table in the back.  It can be a little cramped to play requiring the little pool stick.  Not so good to play with but great to wack your opponent.

The servers are friendly and it's dive bar prices.  It can be a little smokey in there, but besides that it a great spot to kick with your crew.
author: Po L.

description:
SUPER cheap drink specials

FREE popcorn

OLD pool table

I think people have failed to notice that this is a gay bar, because there's not that much gayness to it, except the 2 guys making out in the booth.
author: Laura D.

description:
Bars. Why did it take me this long to think about reviewing all the bars I visit. Doofus. 

So this place. Nice little corner dive. Or is it. WTF counts as a dive in the Mission? They all seem pretty dive-y to me. This one might be more so because they let you smoke in it at night. Am I not supposed to say things like that that might get them in trouble? I cant be bothered to look at other reviews to reference, but whatever. If you dont mind smelling like old aunt Fran's floral print couch after a carton of reds, then head on over. The drinks are drinks. theres free popcorn, you might get to play with the occasional cute puppy. 

Also the staff there is pretty nice. I went twice with my roommate who, when drunk, easily forgets how to act like the independently functioning "adult" that he claims to be. He fell out of his bar stool on the first visit and was asked nicely to leave. I would have kicked him out too, and was relieved that they did because I was definitely ready to go. The second time was same roommates birthday. He was of course plastered when I met him there and proceeded to destroy things inside left and right. 

Anyone else might have killed him, even myself had I been behind the bar. But the gal working that night was SUPER patient and allowed him to live. 

So yeah. Big thanks to the Phone Booth.
author: Alfredo R.

description:
This looks like a job for.... Alcohol!

Despite my desire to see Clark Kent appear at this bar, I had no such luck. I did have the luck, however, to recieve two dollars from the bartender to run in the juke box, which has a pretty super selection. No wonder some woman became all insistent I put on Snow Patrol's Counting cars. With the variety of their hulking cd collection I was also able to put on some Beatles, Violent Femmes, She Wants Revenge, The Subways and Mika. 

The bathrooms have the old style gender symbols, so it was a little funny when my lady friend forgot that the green arrow means it's male, the cross means female. Given the windows into the bathroom though, you don't exactly need X-ray vision to figure it out.

When it came to drinks, a measly $3.75 was all it cost for each beer, that wasn't watered down in the slightest. Trust me, I'm not cool with beers full of aqua, man. The quality of the shots here are also nothing to scoff at, so whatever you need they can hit the bullseye. I just wouldn't be a daredevil and order a martini. It's not that kind of bar.

Not quite a divebar, not quite a hipster bar, Phone booth lingers somewhere in between. If you like either type it's worth stopping by for a quiet night. Or if you bring 40 of your friends, a loud and crazy one.

Jean Grey Wolverine deadpool Cyclops Hawk Girl Gneen Lantern.

Okay, it's out of my system
author: Keith M.

description: It's definitely a dive bar that is deep in the Mission. I guess it is cool that you can smoke there if you smoke... that is all i can say about that...
author: Minh V.

description:
I pepper sprayed a guy here a couple years ago because I thought he was about to assault my roommate.  Okay, so I kinda jumped the gun, but I managed to clear out the entire bar.  Everyone spilled out onto the sidewalk, the bartender chick was going crazy, and all the hipsters were coughing.  I remember hearing some girl mention something about her asthma (I felt really bad).  I thought pepper spray was a straight shot and didn't know the particles were going to dissipate into everyone's lungs, including my own.

Not sure if doing what I did should've gotten me in trouble or not, but since it didn't, I must give this bar 5 stars for tolerating my trigger-happy, party-foul-ing self.  Honestly, I think I was just jonesin' to use my pepperspray on someone :)

If you were there that night, I apologize for any inconvenience.  My roommate and I walked home in silence and never went out together again, and I haven't been back to the Phonebooth since.
author: Karen F.

description:
Do I need to dive into how awesome this bar is? No...

It's awesome, OK? It deserves 5 stars, which if I'm saying that and rating it a "5" that really truly means it rocks! 

FIIIINE, here's a quick rundown of why I love the Phone Booth: 

- free popcorn .
- great red-light ambiance 
- great music on jukebox 
- small place in general --- very intimate/personal
- great pool table 
- interesting patrons (lots of hipsters, but I prefer hipsters to yuppies or rednecks) 
- great memories! (I know this one doesn't really count) 
- good service 
- (this one doesn't apply to me anymore, but) you can smoke inside. 
- great feel inside, love the decor/atmosphere 

SO yeah, 'nuff said. The Phone Booth is my favorite dive bar, period.

And I miss it.
author: Kai S.

description:
Ok, Ok,

I've owed this place a review a long time ago.  The Knockout is where I get my BINGO game fix.  The Phone Booth is where I get my Naked Barbie Doll Chandelier fix.  It was love at first sight.  Not only is it a 3 minute stumble/ crawl from my house, but on any given night, this place is packed to the gills with a friendly, rowdy, sloppy bunch of lookers and ruffians.  

This is where you profess your love and appreciation to your roommates and friends through drunken group hugs.  This is where you help your friends pick up on other gals and guys, and no one is creeped out.  This is where you can talk to your neighbors, crash in on their conversations and everyone will return the love back.  

It's a rowdy oasis smack in the middle of a quiet yet shady mini hood of Mission.  Oh how I love thee.
author: Xandria S.

description:
I had never heard of this place until someone from the neighborhood told me about this hidden little secret. Then the very next night I found myself there.

It's a small. It's a dive. It's dimly lit. There's a pool table in the back. $2 PRB on tap! Not a bad place to kill a few hours with friends.

Oooh, before I forget, there's some impressive kitsch artwork on the walls. Apparently I was so dazzled by the shinny coat of arms up on the wall that I totally missed seeing the Barbie chandler and the popcorn maker!
author: Aria M.

description:
My best friend's arm got fucked up by a crazy drunk who the owner's never reported so I've got some beef with this place. I thought it was homely, why it gotta get all nasty?

Other than that, man, I always have a good time here. Unlike other dive bars the wine isn't god awful, and I can even drink the beer from time to time. Best of all though folks is the juke box. I always learn something new, say a song, whenever I go here. Good selection, great customers who pick great music to listen too.

I need to go back, lest I listen to Lou Reed yet another millionth time in a row.
author: Alexandra M.

description: This is a great neighborhood bar - wish I had one like this close to where I live....or maybe it is good I don't have that temptation...
author: Rick D.

description:
This is hands down my favorite bar in the city.  I love the staff, I love the regulars, I love the jukebox, I love the bathroom!!  I usually go here after work and meet friends here for a drink or two.  The down side is I can usually never find a table and always sit at the bar.  I'm not usually a fan of sitting at the bar, but for the Phone Booth, I'll make and exception ;)

I wish I could in good conscious give this place 0 stars and tell everyone to go away so that I may get a table in the near future, but I can't, this bar is just too great!!!!
author: Jessi K.

description:
Stiff ass drinks.  Tiny bar.  Smoking is allowed inside.  They have popcorn.  Hipsters.  
-Matt
author: Matt N.

description:
Caveat - when a friend and I were hanging out in this bar it was during the middle of the day and we were the ONLY ones in the bar....so I have no idea what the crowd is like, at all.

However, from my experience I plan to definitely go back!!!!! 

-Prices were good
-Good bloody mary (see review below)
-Friendly bartender (Martin was his name)
-Free popcorn

What more could you ask for in a dive bar?  

*******Blood Mary Review**********
The drink I had proved more why it's completely unacceptable to have a bad bloody mary.  

It was obvious that while the bar tender knew how to make a bloody mary, the bar wasn't 'known' for having good bloody mary's or the bartender wasn't necessarily even an excellent craftsman of the drink.   What it proved is with the right ingredients and just a bit of care, a damn fine drink can be made.  It had balance, tasted good from first drink to last drop - it was all I could ask for. 

So I have to ask myself, why is it that even restaurants that have a bloody mary on their special drink menu more often than not make such a crappy drink?  Why is it more often than not that I get a bigger, cheaper, and better tasting bloody mary at a dive bar than at brunch at a restaurant?  

Frustrating!!!!

http://www.yelp.com/redir?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.yelp.com%2Flist_details%3Flist_id%3DYHu-iA23Xj2c1bVa7JROhA
author: Josh M.

description:
I have a feeling this is a place where ANYTHING goes...

maybe the best dive bar I've ever been too??? perhaps.

definitely divey and whores galore.I think i'm in love. This place rulez: smoking, and cigs on the floor. Cheap drinks, and windows into the bathrooms. tiny. dirty. rock n' roll. Definitely a place to get crazy and do some drugs or other things you're too punk to regret..
author: jane l.

description:
I went to Phone Booth over the weekend with a friend of mine after hitting up Truck earlier. 

Wow, this bar is pretty cool. I haven't been to a bar in awhile that allowed smokers to smoke inside. I'm NOT a cigarette smoker, but for some reason the smoke didn't bother me, despite seeing at least 8 people smoking. Stangely enough the smoke kinda added to the cool vibe. Because it's smokey, if you were so inclined, I bet you could get away with smoking the other stuff here too.

I liked the music being played on the jukebox and the bartenders were real nice. I will go back again. 

It seemed to be mostly a straight bar, but me and my gay male friend felt very comfortable. I prefer mixed clientele bars and this one worked just fine. Very cool and tolerant crowd.

Minus 1 star because I wish they had a dart board, since I don't play pool.
author: Yvette K.

description:
A big group of us went here after the Super Bowl. It was crowded (but not too crowded) and some of the patrons were belligerent (a little too belligerent). Some perv was hitting on & arguing with my friend, which wasn't cool, but I was able to ignore that freak and listen to the many good songs available on the jukebox. Plus, the bartender periodically checked on us to see if we wanted drinks, which is good. The only downside (other than the perv) is that it was way too smoky, despite the big no smoking sign.

Also, they sell pitchers of beer for $9.

I'm giving it 4 stars. If I hadn't smelled like smoke/death I'd rate it 5.
author: Wes F.

description:
I like this place.  It is a good dive bar and usually not too crowded.  Drinks are good, good price and good poor.  I would visit more often if it wasn't a smoke house.  Bartenders are usually super cool as well.

Pros:
Good drinks, good price.

Cons:
Smokey.
author: Ted t.

description:
I can see the appeal, I mean, if it was my neighborhood I'd be down to go here on random week nights.

But I went on a Saturday night with friends and it was a tad far from me in the TL, and it was too crowded.  Couldn't order drinks, couldn't sit down, couldn't get out!  The door was blocked by morons who wouldn't move out of the way.  I hate feeling trapped.  Also, it smelled hot and funky.  I ended up going home before my friend attempted to order me a drink.  They stayed however and I guess had fun.

Just not my cup of tea for a Saturday night.
author: Mary R.

description:
ME: "Operator, I'd like the number to the Phone Booth"
OPERATOR: "You'd like a number to a phone booth?"
ME: "No, it's a bar"
OPERATOR: "You'd like the number to a phone booth inside a bar???"
ME: "Sheesh"

DIAL TONE.

WIth that aside, this establishment lies in the top three of my bars of choice in the city. You can get beers in a can. A martini in the proper glass, and the usual fare with friendly tenders behind the bar.

It has a pool table probably not regulation size b/c of the small size of the room, probably the size of a large phone booth, haha. I've heard complaints from some girl companions about the peeping tom views of the bathrooms, i say, flaunt it bitches!

And then there's the smoke. I'm a weird smoker, i only buy packs when i'm in bukowski writing modes which is 3 or 4 months out of the year. People do chain smoke here, but usually not at the counter. But your clothes will wreak of parliaments, i say, smell it bitches!

There is the hip factor especially at party time on the weekends which can annoy. One insulted me, "what accent did you lose?". Hehe, good one, it's going in the script.

The juke is better than most with some electro and cheese metal, and the crowd can shake to it.
author: wayne s.

description:
You scene-worriers, relax. The lemmings are only annoying if you deign to take them seriously. They are zoo animals, take a gander. laugh aloud. When you are having the most fun, you are in charge.

And there's no better place for all this then the Phone booth! Cheap drinks in a pocket-sized bar, with a Barbie chandelier! Earlier is better for sitting and chatting, and the smoked sardine experience starts up later.
author: j r.

description:
God bless it, I love the Phone Booth. That there is a place in San Francisco where I can smoke, eat free popcorn, sing along to both Wham and Interpol and get my shit rocked for $3.50 a glass makes me believe in Jesus again. 

The good news is this place is one of my top three favorite bars in the city. The bad news is it's everyone else's top three favorites. Don't show up here at Rock O'Clock and expect to do anything except share a stool with a cute and slightly smelly hipster in a scarf, otherwise you'll be wearing your cranky pants. That said, it's just a happy place to be.
author: Jaime S.

description:
BAD WAY TO TREAT A 1ST TIME LOCAL CUSTOMER-  WHAT A BAD TASTE LEFT IN OUR MOUTHS!

My friend from UCSF and I heard that this place was really chill and served strong and cheap drinks, and they do... BUT BEWARE:

When they were about to close, my friend was exchanging numbers with a girl when the doorman/bouncer asked us to leave.  I being one-drink sober told the guy they were exchanging numbers and my friend was killing his beer.  He stood next to us, AND ONLY US, even though there were 15 other people still there. His hipster and attitude-laden response was that ALL of the other people had "permission". 

He pulls my friend up and says, "Finish your drink and leave!"  As my friend went to finish, the bar employee POURS THE BEER ALL OVER THE FLOOR.  MY FRIEND HAD JUST PAID FOR IT AND WAS ABOUT TO DRINK (so we could leave).  Obviously, after this a**hole door guy push my friend's drink over my friend was pissed and demanded his money back and an apology. The nice women working the bar offered him the money but the door guy wouldn't apologize. 

WHAT fucking pretentious attitude to show after we spend money and time quietly chilling at their bar. NOT THE WAY TO TREAT CUSTOMERS, even if you allow smoking in your bar you still need customer service. 

Great atmosphere -too bad the people who work there have an attitude problem. The two girls behind the bar could not have been nicer, too bad that one guy ruined out 1st impression, not going back soon!
author: Max K.

description:
I need to go to the Phone Booth more and say hi to the black velvet panther, I've been missing it the last few weeks.

The Phone Booth does something to its drinks --- they are strong beyond all reason and well mixed so it's hard to tell sometimes.  I go in for one beer and end up confused 6 hours later with a massive drunk and yet I still manage to have at least 1/3 of the money in my pockets that I started out with.  I remember when the Lawrence and Garner v. Texas ruling came down, I was sitting in the Booth and the whole bar cheered, something along the lines of "Woo-hoo! sodomy!"  It was really a very touching sense of community goodwill that suffused the place.
 
I am also glad to report that the cabs full of "slumming" frat-trash seem to have stopped pulling up outside and hence the bar has gone back to its traditional mellow mixed (age and sexuality) Bernal/Mission crowd, even on weekends.
author: Gustie L.

description:
Why is it every time I go to this bar, someone winds up making out on the pool table? I think that table sees more lovin than it ever does actual pool. 

My favorite pool table pas de deux? The gay man/straight woman tango in which the gentleman in question lavishly twirled and strutted with his partner, and leaned her back onto the pool table (her legs went up in the air in a perfect "V" - water ballet style) before dipping her (nearly to the floor) in front of his friends and yelling to them "I can't handle this vagina!!!" 

He said it with obvious enthusiasm. As in "Wow. This vagina is driving me insane with dance madness." 

And that is why I love the phone booth. Also, the drinks are cheap.
author: H. S.

description:
Cheap drinks, awesome jukebox and a pool table... so what's not to like about the Phone Booth?

* Cigarette smoke.  You forget how gross cigarettes are until the smoke gets in your eyes, and on your clothes... even one of the bartenders was smoking.

* It's cold.  Maybe it was just a Thursday night thing, but both front doors were open and it was cold at the bar and cold in the bathroom -- which, by the way, is filthier than what you'll encounter at most gas stations.

I like dives, and damn if the Phone Booth doesn't have one of the best jukeboxes I've seen in all of the Bay Area, but I won't be going back anytime soon.
author: Daniel S.

description: Strong, cheap drinks. Interesting jukebox with everything from the Gossip to Belinda Carlisle. Smokers. Dirty. Dark. Friendly people. Generally awesome.
author: Kimberley D.

description:
Going here on a weekend can be a mixed bag -- if you get a table you can keep to yourself it's okay, if you can't then it's pretty much hell.

The real reason to come here is the staggering cocktails they pour, and for cheap. We're talking six-or-seven-second pours for three dollars. You can get drunk for cheaper, but it involves a brown bag and a pint of Taaka. Go on a weeknight when you're looking to get trashed early.
author: Jake S.

description:
I'd give this local watering hole five stars, but the smoking inside made me only give the Phone Booth four stars.

It was earlier on Friday evening when I was there, loved the jukebox, and the bartender, who wasn't outwardly friendly, but did make a good vodka martini that I requested be extra dirty (pornographic actually, as I like to call them). 

The crowd was mixed, both gay and straight, and many people sang along when their favorite song came on, including a rowdy rendition of "9 to 5" from Dolly Parton.
