Overall, this was a place that you really need to have some drinks at, it's that much fun. Just be sure if cigarette smoke bothers you, get ready to hold your breath.
author: David G.

description: love this place. I was there for a minute on Saturday night but it was crowded so we stepped out. The bartenders are cool, the drinks are always cheep and the poor is always heavy. What more can you ask for.
author: josh m.

description:
Great dive-y bar. Weird stuff hanging from the ceiling.
Good place to get a table with friends. Pool table. 
It's far enough from the epicenter of bridge-and-tunnel (16th/Mission area) that they either don't know about it or it's too far for them to venture. 
There is smoking inside but as a nonsmoker it's never really bothered me.
author: Kelly B.

description:
Chicagoans: This bar is like a mixture of The Empty Bottle and Hungry Brain.

I came here on a Sunday afternoon and there was a great crowd. Mostly older men that didn't look like they'd hang out at a hipster bar. But they were sweet and the clientele changes the later in the day it gets. 

Super cool bartender and even super cool-er Barbie chandelier. Good stuff on the jukebox. it was just my speed. Not sure if it is this cool on a weekend night, but I loved it.
author: Kera E.

description:
My first experience with The Phone Booth was on a St. Patrick's Day when the Mission was overrun with Marina and bridge/tunnel douchebags vomiting in the gutters.  Seriously, what's wrong with you guys that you can't hold your booze, especially when all you're drinking is green PBR?  (Also, as an aside to other Yelpers, please note the your/you're distinction.)

Anyway, a small group of us wandered into The Phone Booth and found it unpolluted by the aforementioned douchebags.  The bartender was friendly and fast, which serves as a nice contrast to, for example, The Dovre Club, and we were able to chill with some booze in a companionable atmosphere.  TPB is the place to go if you just want to kick back with a drink, talk with your friends, and feel welcome.
author: Bitter J.

description:
cool, low key dive bar.

awesome jukebox.
author: Anne B.

description:
This was the first bar I got wasted in when I moved to San Francisco.

They make really, really, REALLY strong drinks.

I threw up in the bathroom and there wasn't a working lock on the door so a bunch of people came in on me. I don't know about you, but I like my privacy when I'm throwing up. Short bathroom stall doors, too.
author: Maren C.

description: This place is alright to me. It gets super packed, and I didn't care much for the music. The cigarette aspect was both nice and frightful. The best part besides the cheap beer had to be the creepy naked Barbie chandelier. Oh, and free popcorn.
author: Lauren S.

description: Always the place I come to when I have friends in town.  Great beer selection and the $4 Hoegardens can't be beat.  The jukebox is also always rockin'.  Smoke!!!!!
author: Sin F.

description:
Excellent neighborhood bar, period.

Okay, I take that period part back because otherwise this would be an annoyingly super-short review.

First off, the bartenders are solid.  They aren't looking to be your pal, but they are friendly enough and pour good, stiff drinks.

Second, yes it is small.  If you are afraid of someone brushing past you, then don't go.  Come to think of it, better move out of the City entirely.  Don't plan on finding a seat after ten on a weekend, but does this really matter?  You are there to drink, enjoy good company, drink, listen to the excellent juke box and drink.

C. And as for crowd, yes, you will see a few bad shag haircuts, skinny jeans and ironic t-shirts, i.e., people we all like to mock as "hipsters," but you will only notice if you are bored with your own company (and not paying sufficient attention to drinking) and need something to talk about.

Ok, now period.
author: Padraig M.

description:
I hereby dedicate my 100th Yelp review to my favorite San Francisco bar, The Phone Booth.

I don't think it's an exaggeration to say that this bar is one of the reasons I stayed in the City during those first few difficult months of living here. After a day or a week of feeling out of place, lonely, wondering what in the world a midwestern girl like me was doing in a crazy city like this, I would sidle up to the bar at the Phone Booth, order a well vodka and cran for $3, and my worldview would immediately improve.

Their prices have gone up a bit since then, but they still have some of the cheapest drinks around, and definitely the strongest.  The bartenders are friendly and the jukebox is one of the best.  It gets a bit hipstered out on the weekends, but if you get there early or go on a weeknight, it will be the bar of your dreams.  If you're me.

I have peed in the alley around the corner at the beginning of a long trudge home.  I have celebrated two birthdays here.  I have secret pet names for the bartenders.  I have fed lots of quarters to the great jukebox. I have smoked lots of cigarettes inside.  I have danced and played pool and been heckled by the regulars.

I don't get down here as much as I'd like to these days, but this bar will always hold a special place in my heart.
author: Megan D.

description:
The bartenders can be hit or miss here, sure the bar stinks, yes when you go home you can't recycle the clothes you wore because they reek of smoke, sure it gets super crowded as the night progresses, I know the popcorn- no matter how fresh it is- never tastes fresh.

But I have a love for this bar because of all the good times we have had together, and nothing can ever take those away.  All those drunken half-blank memories of taking happy hour way passed the happy hours.  Remembering the nights when Sara would slip us an xtra shot now and then.  All those PBR/Whiskey specials.  The Tall cans of Tecate stacking high on our table.  The jukebox playing AC/DC's "Hells Bells", followed by the overplayed "Jolene" by Dolly Parton.  The time spent wondering why anyone would hang up a picture of Tom Sellec.  The nights stumbling my way back to my friends house down the street, waking up and wondering how I got home, and why did I feel so friggin sick, and then I get a whiff of my jacket and I knew I had been at the phone booth.
author: Bone D.

description:
Love the small, intimate and unassuming bar setting.

Love the mix of locals and hipsters.

Love the pool table.

Love the free popcorn.

Love the jukebox with a rotating and eclectic selection of some really great tunes.

Love the properly poured and priced mixed drinks.  Just your basics though, they'll give you the stare down if you ask for anything more complicated than a Jack and Coke.

Love the bar special of Jamesons and Ginger Juice.  Spicy and strong.

Love the friendly bartenders.

Hate the attitude some of the bartenders give you if you aren't a recognized local.

Hate the pseudo-private and claustrophobic bathroom that doesn't quite lock and that you can sort of see into if you try. 

Hate the cooler -than-thou hipsters.

Hate the chain-smoking-cooler-than-thou hipsters.

Hate the chain-smoking-cooler-than-thou hipsters taking over your table and pretending like they don't notice what is going on.
author: Sharon R.

description: surly bartenders, affordable swill, jukebox jumps and just a lot of goddamn fun!  see you there
author: Mike M.

description:
I puked inside the bar, on a bench and on some chicks hair.. and they let me back in after the kind bar back cleaned it up and when i was done  after a breather.

thats awesome..

I usually go for Dolly PArton, jesus And Mary Chain, Prince.. on the jukebox...

i cant understand all this resentment against so called hipsters.. i mean i have no idea what a hipster is?  do they even exist? I get along with everyone.. for the most part... and if people wanna keep to themselves, so be it.. if somebody bugs me, i avoid them politely.. maybe the person who has  a gripe, is annoying..
author: Georgio S.

description:
Stephie went to Phonebooth for her friend's 21st, because her friend was trying to get laid by a midget douche.  Aren't the midget douches the worst?  It seems the shorter you get as a douche, the more insulting it is to the senses.  Anyway, some weird troll looking guy entertained her by barking nonsense and screaming at his dog, Joseph.  Stephie, being a comedic genius herself, sensed that he was trying to be funny and appreciated it, because hanging out while your friend tries to get laid by a midget douche for her 21st birthday is pretty, pretty, pretty.... lame.

Stephie says don't bother washing your hands after the bathroom.

Mikey says, "what's phonebooth?"
author: Steph and Mike A.

description: It a great dive bar they have good cheap drinks and the service was excellent . So many regulars were having a good time and we started talking with them and they started telling us stories about this place.
author: Yoen K.

description: Pretty much no bar is worth walking into a cloud of cigarette smoke, and Phone Booth is no exception.  I'm sure if i liked smoking i would disagree with myself, so don't bother pointing this out to me.  Sure, the drinks might be cheap and strong, the juke box might be rare and exceptional (i wouldn't know).  But let's be honest: hipster bars are a dime a dozen in the mission, most are smoke free, and i'm fine with paying a quarter more per beer to not smell like someone else's second hand smoke tomorrow AM.
author: Melodie S.

description: my neighborhood hipster dive.  drinks are priced fairly.  a good to great jukebox, that lays heavy on the Duran Duran - could do without the Lady Gaga cd in there (though I'm told it has since been removed).  word of warning tho, lots of smokers.  a good place to go when yr alone at 12:30pm.
author: eric i.

description:
If you are gonna hate, please don't come to this bar. We don't want you here, we don't want you to eat our popcorn and we don't want you crowding our space. 

I am sorry if you are too self-conscious and busy looking at everyone else to enjoy the super-cheap drinks and fabulous atmosphere. 

This is the first bar I ever went to in SF and after 3 years it is still my favorite!  It's one of the only spots left that hasn't been corrupted by the far reaching claws of the Marina-in-the-Mission weekend movement, and it's  not nearly as hipstery and obnoxious as Pops.

I am lucky enough to live a block away and call this my neighborhood bar. Strong cheap drinks, great jukebox, free popcorn and good friends! What more could you want?
author: Javier B.

description:
Eww, smoking in bars... gross. I hate it when that smoke lingers on your clothes for days. And its hipster central! Its like American Apparel opened a dive bar.

Though not my scene, the drinks were pretty cheap, and if you smoke, own a bike, and refer yourself as a 'hipster', I can see it being a fun place to be. I'll take my fresh air over this anyday. *cough cough*.
author: Rocky K.

description:
Not much to say about this little number other than: Smoke. Popcorn. Pool. Drink. Sweet jukebox. 
Clearly a bar designed for smokers so all you pompous SF yoga health freaks out there stay clear and need not let another good place go shit. RIP Amber Lounge.
author: Jessica U.

description: A fun narrow little bar, interesting painting and kooky decorations.   But a point off for being a smoking bar (people don't even bother to hold their cigarette low or be considerate of other patrons -- I'm not saying you have to go outside, but don't blow it in other people's faces). And another point off for the crowd -- a little too cool for school. Truly cool people don't need to broadcast it...
author: Vanessa H.

description: Scary on the outside but fun on the inside.  It did have a bit of a Castro vibe to it with the way it was decorated.  All of these silver painted branches popping out of the wall.  It gave me the impression that some queen from the Castro tried to put a fancy touch on the place.  It didn't work for me but I did enjoy playing pool.
author: Scott P.

description:
Have you checked out the bathroom situation at Phone Booth?
It is SO FREAKING COOL.
I'm serious. You walk up to a green window/door and look through and you see the toilet behind another door and in this way you can tell if someone is in there. It is immaculate and delightful to use these toilets. At least the Women's. 

Oh..The bar itself. Right.
It's rockin', too. They had some nice Halloween decor up when I went.
author: Addyline L.

description:
I have had so many varied experiences here.  Some nights are just awesome.  Cool music, cheap drinks and a fun crowd.  Other nights it is so packed that your date has to stand on your feet. There is just nothing fun about that.  I mean, I know 'the phone booth'... it is small.  But there are better ways to set up a bar than just haphazardly throw 8 tables and a handful of chairs into the space and 'let the bar configure itself.

Also, is everyone that goes here from the old Kilowatt crowd?  Seems like the same vibe as that joint circa 1999-2000.
author: Thadd L.

description:
You can smoke in here, which is cool if you do, but I don't and I stank afterwards :(

People were nice. Bartender was nice enough (except she kept keeping our change without asking..).  Good enough on a Monday night.
author: Wendy T.

description:
An excellent little neighborhood bar that over the years has turned into a hipster haven. Long ago, you would find the most interesting mix of Mexican tranny's, blue collar locals, and random folks who happened upon The Booth for the first time.

Luckily they still have the popcorn and the pool table.
author: Chris I.

description:
Popcorn + Cheap Drinks = Heaven. I love the bartenders. i love that I can have 'dinner' here by stuffing myself silly with free popcorn while I down deliciously cheap vodka sodas. I love how many crazy evenings have started or ended here.

I would give it five starts except for them advertising on their menu a super cheap bottle of champagne which I've only been able to have once. Every other time I've asked they're out of it. And that one time I was so gone already that I might have imagined it. Then again that's probably a good thing because if they started offering bottles of Cooks on the menu, I would probably never leave.
author: Jen M.

description:
Cheap beer, a chandelier made out of Barbies, laid back people.  If you happen to have a birthday cake on hand, the bartender will provide you with a knife for cutting the cake.  You can even smoke inside!

All in all this place would merit 5 stars but for the snarky person at the bar who mocked the fact that I used the word "like" in a sentence when I asked the bartender if I could borrow a knife.  Please dude, I don't need your sass!
author: Katina M.

description: Bring a friend to the Phone Booth and you'll leave being solid BFFs forever as you share secrets over those giant cans of Tecate. Snuggle up at the bar and be entertained by hilarious patrons and a bartender with a wicked sense of humor. Enjoy a strong pour in a $4 cocktail. This place is one of my favs - it is what it is. Unapologetic dive bar. If you dislike this type of bar, stay out and take your whiny yelp review with you. Bleh.
author: Allegra F.

description:
$4 cocktails?? I'm in! 

It's the definition of dive. Jukebox, unpretentious, dimly lit, you can smoke inside (or at least it smells like you can), cheap drinks, and 1 bartender. $1 @ the jukebox gets you 3 songs, and the selection is pretty good too. 

This is the perfect place to get the night started and then move down Valencia to the various other watering holes. I'll definitely be back!
author: Yee-Shing W.

description:
P Booth is the truth.  Its got an amazing jukebox, a delightfully worn pool table and I always run into friends there.  Always.  But the best part is definitely the drinks: the bartenders measure booze like 60s pot dealers and its almost always an eight finger count.  Seriously, I had friends from LA up here and they could not believe how much Makers you get in a drink for five bucks.  

I'm a Makers and ginger guy and now they even have some special home made ginger concoction that is perfect for getting sauced when you got a cold.  Really good shit.  

Now if they only had Racer...
author: Gianpaolo P.

description:
I like to call it "Smokey the Bar." Anita is awesome and it's a bar you can smoke in. Don't get me wrong I like not being able to smoke in bars but when you're sitting at the bar PBR in one hand Makers rocks in the other you don't want to leave that moment to go out and smoke. It's slows down the getting drunk for cheap process.

I LOVE SMOKEY THE BAR!!!!
author: Prestin B.

description: best smoking bar in town, great music
author: Peadar K.

description:
A nice spot to come in for a quick drink, or a place to linger for a while taking in the decent jukebox and loud chatter of the other patrons.  The bartenders are always friendly, and there is a good selection of both draught beer and liquor.  

Be warned, it is tiny, and a trip to the loo will most likely require waiting for a shot of pool to be played.

It's the closest thing I've found to my favorite hangout  (back in NC) so far in SF.
author: GeneR S.

description: Prior to his nonsensical ramblings in The Expendables Mickey Rourke was cast in a film called Bar Fly. Portraying a rough and tumble alcoholic poet his character occupied a space at a down town dive bar, over-running his tab, picking fights with the local steady and making a mess of himself in the company of any female who would entertain his type. This film romanticised, in a peculiar way, the American dive bar. An establishment operating with the sole purpose of getting its clientele well and truly liquored for a reasonable amount of money. The Phone Booth is the last remaining homage to the great American dive bar. Located off Mission this locals-only haunt consists of an old, unkept bar serviced by disinterested bar staff, a stained old pool table and a gang of faithful natives all of which seem to pay no regard to the recently imposed national smoking bans. It was refreshing to find an establishment that operates under an unspoken client-staff agreement, you do what you want and we will tell nobody. A bar that never measures drinks, plays the bartenders ipod and allows everyone to smoke inside; a seemingly blatant middle finger to the powers to be. I recommend staying till close on a Saturday night just to witness the crass but highly effective approach the bar tenders take when clearing their place of business. The Phone Booth is a diamond in the rough, the last Lost Boys club, be ready to drink and enjoy your favourite unsavoury past times.
author: ryan b.

description: When I go into a dive bar I generally stick with beer to avoid getting poisoned by the lowest of the low end alcohols so often kept on bottom shelves at these establishments. However, last night I wanted something a little tastier and the adorable Monday night bartender whipped me up a cosmo (and then another. and then another). I could not stop talking to my friend about how good it was all night. So much fresh squeezed lime and little chips of ice floating on the top, just like it should be done. One star off because personally I think smoking inside is way gross.
author: B. C.

description:
one recent evening, i was hanging out with friends of a friend at the phone booth.  i didn't know these people too well and honestly, i'm pretty sure i didn't want to.  however, i felt like i must charm the pants off of them and have them all secretly or not so secretly in love with me by evening's end or else my entire sense of self worth is out the window.  i'm totally insane/insecure like that.  the problem with this particular night was that due to a fairly large amount of alcohol consumption earlier in the evening, the laura b charm machine was set on TOTALLY FUCKING NUTS.  

conversation went a little like this:

scenester #1:  i'm in a band.

laura b:          BANDS ARE GREAT!

scenester #2:  cool.  so am i.  where does your band play?

scenester #1:  makeout room...

laura b:           I LOVE THE MAKE OUT ROOM!

scenester #1:  (continuing) ...a couple other places, ya know.

scenester #2:  cool.  me too.

laura b:           I AM NOT IN A BAND!

scenester #1:  (bummed out sounding) yeah, but we don't have any gigs until september.

laura b:           AUGUST IS A BULLSHIT MONTH!!!!

all scenesters:  silence.

laura b:           i'll take a jack and coke, please!

the rest of the evening was pretty much spent engaging the bartender in a round of, "what color underwear is that girl wearing?"  which seems like an innocent enough game until the tables are turned on you.  this would mistakenly appear to be the   low point of the night but actually, i believe that came when i drunk dialed my own parents.  I DRUNK DIALED MY OWN PARENTS.  this ended in a lecture about my substance dependency issues and the fact that i am 28 and on a road to nowhere and will probably die alone with 16 pit bulls and a mean case of regret.  MY OWN PARENTS!!!!  totally fucked up night.

all of my memories of the phone booth pretty much roll like that.  which is to say, pretty lamely.  everyone here is trying just about as hard as the juke box.  see ben v's review for more info on THAT.
author: Laura B.

description: Love this dive bar, great mission scene
author: Scott R.

description: Love the vibe at the Phone Booth. GREAT jukebox and cheap drinks. My only quarrel is that they let people smoke in the bar. I always leave stinking of cigarettes. Boo to that.
author: Christina S.

description:
i rang in the new year here last night. the decor was 'heavenly' and they gave out free champagne. besides this, my drinks were cheap and tasty and when the new year hit a monkey ran in and jumped around for us all and i kissed someone i love.  also, i was given free pot which was vaporized shortly thereafter. i also experienced riding on the back of a bike for the 1st time and all in all, celebrating at the PB was not too shabby if ya ask me...  since my evening prior to the PB consisted of a shitty mission crawl, i was happy to have not gotten stabbed or puked on.


here's to a happy new year everyone!!!
author: Karen K.

description:
A jukebox can be a very telling piece of anthropological evidence when evaluating a bar.  Put in context with this bar's patrons, everything starts to make sense.  Let's say you're into "punk", well, we've The Clash, a little Go-go's (for the ladies) and you know, like The Stooges.  Oh, so you're so hip and unique your thing is "soul" music, well we've got some Aretha Franklin for ya.  Oh, so you're a "rocker," well we've got Nirvana, a little Motley Crue.  Or maybe it's the 80's you're vibin', well we've got some Billy Idol, a little Duran Duran.  Oh, wait, you're one of those people who truly is just interested in hipster fashion, well, for you we've got some Coldplay, a little Killers, you know, all the new hip musical accessories.  Like, seriously is this place a joke?  Bar owner: "Let's take the most generic, pop culture examples of each genre of indie subculture and throw them together on our jukebox.  I'm sure our patrons, who dress, look and act like they've just scratched the surface of this subculture themselves won't see our ironic grin."  
This bar is crowded, smoky, exceedingly dark, and you can't even break on the pool table without brushing your stick up against a nautical star tattooed arm or some buttock in a pair Seven jeans looking to fuck an "artist".  Before 9pm it's a decent place to have a conversation and a beer, so it gets an extra star for that, but like, for real.  Who are these people and what do they stand for?
author: Ben V.

description: Everything about this bar is perfect, except for the smoke that assails you as soon as you walk in the door. Cheap, good drinks (including some specialty drinks you wouldn't expect), great bartenders, a pool table, and a good variety of people that are usually in a good mood. One of the reasons I give it top marks is their holiday decorations. They are always really creative and well done.
author: Cyrelle D.

description: For all the time I spend here I might as well be on the lease. Asking me why I love the Phone Booth is like asking your soulmate why she loves you. It's just this incredibly strong feeling inside. Small as the name implies, smoky, drinks about fifty cents cheaper than most places, an excellent jukebox and central location (25th and South Van Ness) -- I don't even know if it's better than most places because to me it's the only bar in town. A recurring cast of interesting characters helps, and a different atmosphere from most Mission watering holes. Nobody comes here to get stinking drunk, just to have a great time and leer at the occasional tragic hipster who stumbles in.
author: Davi M.

description: There was a time when PB was S.O.P. for a Monday night but that ended when Tuesdays got to be way too shitty. There are a couple of great bartenders but then the opposite side of the spectrum is well represented too. Most evenings you will find a pool table, a great jukebox, stale popcorn and depending on what you look like, serious attitude from far to many of your fellow patrons. I should really accept that I am old and crotchety because I am so over the crowd here.  Marina pretension is based on making more money than you. Mission pretension is based on being "hipper" than you. Same douche, different uniform. Two stars for some pretty good memories.
author: Mingus R.

description: Saturday was the night of the Michael M. great hipster bar crawl of 2009. We went to Uptown. We went to the Make Out Room. We went to the Attic. We went to Pops. Only when we went to the Phone Booth did the real fun start. The music was killing it. People were dancing on chairs, dancing with the bouncers, moving their hips around the pool table. Everyone was having a good time. It was like the red room in Santa Cruz, but better. The red room of yesteryear. I love the decor. The bartenders are nice (rare in a hip dive like this, can you say pretentious?). Even when we were there after the last call the staff generally treated us with respect for the fun we were having. Overall The Phone Booth is quickly becoming my favorite dive east of Valencia (that is some fierce competition).
author: Michael M.

description: Strong, cheap cocktails (my vodka sunrise was only $4). The place is pretty small, but the lighting and overall ambiance is pretty nice.
author: Faith A.

description: This bar is pretty great  - until it gets more than half full. Too many hipsters with ironic tatoos, too many smokers, too many lame conversations and the average age is 24. If you are a young hipster who wants to chain smoke, binge drink and hook up with tatooed strangers who dress like bike messengers BUT ARE NOT bike messengers - then check this place out. If you are mature you probably won't like it.
author: Pucktart T.

description: With the sultry red lighting, Phone Booth looks a lot like a smaller version of The Attic, a Mission favorite of mine.  But the scene here is a lot fringier, right down to the Van Ness & 25th edge-of-nowhere location.  There were a few classy hipsters (myself included of course), but a lot of the patrons had taken the chain-smoking counterculture thing into the realm of sketchiness...at least that's the vibe I got.  Oddly, the jukebox blared a hell of a lot of cheesy 80's music.  I was too busy car-bombing my PBR & Jameson to determine what level of irony that amounted to.  All told, it's worth having in your Mission bar-folio, but not going to be my first destination.
author: Wes M.

description: Ended up here already half soused with a group of friends, we migrated from an obnoxiously loud and overcrowded bar where it was impossible to move or carry on a convo.  We immediately felt better about the whole situation upon entering and being seated.  A few of us ran into old friends we hadn't seen in years, the place was dim, the music good, the queers loudmouthed and smartassed (just the way i like em!).  The bar served cheap, strong drinks, the smoking happened within.  The bathroom was reasonably clean, and i liked that it was multi-use stall/urinal/sink.  I had a fabulous convo with a random stranger in line for said potty.  Basically it was like candyland with booze!  Long lost friends and loudmouthed queers and nearly clear rum-n-cokes.  Fuckin-A Phone Booth, where have you been all my life?
author: RJ M.

description: So, in moving from a little diddy in the central valley just south of this city, I grew up with the idea of treasuring local dives and cherishing them as a place "....where everybody knows your name."  Well I'm always glad when I came, or come, or go, to Phone Booth.  Nobody knows me there and really I've only been there a handful of times.  But, the bar absolutely is a corner home where our neighborhood can count on good music, no incredibly crowded scene of people and reasonable prices.  Oh Phone Booth--"I like you just the way you are!"
author: Nicole d.

description:
pros:
- cheap drinks
- bartenders under charge half of the time
- best juke box in SF
- black cougar velvet painting
- best mix of people
- I FORGOT THE BARBIE CHANDELIER!!!!

cons:
- hipsters (although i can't fault anyone for being 20)
- smoking (sorry, I had enough of smoky bars in Chicago and smelling like white trash)
- bartenders that when you try to break into their 10 minute conversation about the band they are in, get pissy

Other than the above, I love this place.

(ps  to the very large drunk girl  that came up to me and slapped my boyfriend for no reason - who slaps a gay man thats not another gay? - and I knocked into the jukebox, you should have apologized to everyone in there for skipping that great song!)
author: J J.

description: This is my favorite neighborhood bar. I'm a bit confused as to why it is being dubbed a hipster hangout because the crowd is as diverse as the neighborhood it occupies. If you don't feel comfortable there, go somewhere else. Yes it can be crowded and yes it can be smokey, like all proper dive bars should be.  I have nothing but love for Phone Booth.
author: Bonnie B.

description:
Since I live right around the corner, I try not to wear out my welcome at The Phone Booth... but I have such a great time when I go that its getting very hard!

Star 1: Strong drinks. Their beer selection is typical for a dive, [PBR, Olympia, Anchor Steam, etc] but now I opt for strictly mixed drinks because they are crafted with care and a heavy hand. For about $4.
Star 2: Indoor smoking. Even though I'm trying to quit, its nice to not have all my friends leave to go outside when they want one. 
Star 3: It can read my mind. I swear, whenever I go to this bar, its set to the exact mood I'm in. From a pool game, after-work unwind, or catching up with a friend, it all works here.
Star 4: Solid Jukebox. I usually have a bit of distain for jukebox bars, [music should be part of the atmosphere, not something you have to pay extra for!] but TPB has the best bar music. A hearty selection of '70's-'90's rock [read: New Order, Replacements, Mac, Bowie] plus enough new shit to appease hipsters. MGMT fans need not apply.
Star 5: The Phone Booth really came through for me and my friends this year with a bangin' Halloween Party! Totally unexpected from this understated dive, but when I had a house full of people with no idea where to go, we were blown away by the dj's, costume contest and general debauchery of this bar's All Hallow's celebration. 

all in all, this is the kind of bar I would run myself, so I will continue to show it love.
author: Lauren C.

description:
there are framed photos of tom jones & tom selleck above the bar, which i noticed immediately for the sake of my friend nicole, who is kind of obsessed with them both.

i wrote her this haiku:

toms selleck and jones
'cole's pants are totally wet
she loves the phone booth

bars that inspire writings of this kind (amazing) are obviously worth drinking in.
author: Irene S.

description: The Booth used to be one of my favorite Mission dives untill I moved too far away to make it a regular venture.  They have a good juke box, a fun mixed crowd, a pool table and cheap man-cans of Tacate.  I subtracted 1/568th of a star for every time I have been in there when it was too crowded to get to the bar when I desperatly needed a refill.  While you're waiting to get to the bar you can enjoy a cool smoking, slow burning Camel brand filtered cigarrette because they let you smoke inside.  Now I'm in flavor country.
author: jason k.

description: This used to be my post-El Rio-spot when I lived in the Mission.  You can smoke in here, there's a Barbie Chandelier, and the place is so damn dark that you can't tell if you're talking to your friend or some random stranger.  But who cares.
author: Sarah S.

description: This place is the best.  We ended up here after a full day at the beach and what a way to cap the day off, but to have a couple of drinks at the bar.  Liz  and Robert give good pour.  The jukebox is pretty fracking good- little bit of some new stuff (mika) and some oldies (dusty).  It's nice to see people dancing their asses off at 7pm to Michael Jackson. It's the perfect little neighborhood bar.
author: Valarie A.

description: This is such a little  local jewel, a great juke box agin just a sliver but just like the name suggests it dares to pack everyone in. And like any great dive bar there is always a clever mix of hipster and old kook. There is pool and a popcorn machine but what really strikes my fancy is the long bench and adjoing chairs and tables allowing to make friends or hold a pack of friends as stated it is a smoking speakeasy at night which can be a blessing on those chilly nights. The drink specials always invite cheap drunken times. Take your out of towners they'll love it.  Did I mention the dark red moody bordello atmosphere with heavy drizzle of kitch? well I did now.
author: crystal j.

description: 3 draft Pabsts for $6 (seems like the minimum unit), 1/2 block from my house and possibly the hottest bartender chick in the history of the free world... a great great bar if it's not too smoky.  Go on a weeknight, otherwise you can't breathe.  "Jolene" more than likely on the jukebox on any given entrance.  Why is dolly parton hip now?  There's a limit to the irony of "9-to-5"...
author: Scott C.

description: Dragged here after a night of drinking and a burrito at el farolito. Drinking again so soon after the greasy burrito was probably not the best idea. Should've digested a bit first. But drink I did. And holy crap, their drinks are strong. Jack and coke? 80% jack, 20% coke. Vodka tonic? 80% vodka, 20% tonic. Might as well have just taken shots. And you can smoke inside. Cool.
author: The Sock S.

description: THREE friends have recommended Phone Booth "because Matt Roberts drinks there."  What is this guy, Collin Farrell? More like Collin Quinn! HAHAHAHAHAHAHAAA!  Anyway, sure, it's a hip bar and sure, it's crowded.  But it's suprisingly unassuming (for its coolness) and negotiable (as far as ease of movement).  I always have a good time here and it's the Mission bar I lobby for when everyone's dragging their thrift store Adidases.
author: J P.

description: smoking still flies in this bar.  if you are a smoker, wooho!  If you don't smoke, well, your clothes are going to need to be dry cleaned.   Great on weekdays when its not busy.  Weekends bring with it a much younger hipster clientele that can't real fit into the small space
author: BeeryMcGymrat X.

description: This place rocks- it reminds me of "boat" in Brooklyn.  It has a kick-ass jukebox and a great ambiance.  The pool table is usually open.  The owner is really friendly and the prices are reasonable.
author: Damien S.

description: This is my favorite bar to go to in the city. They have great music, and the wonderful combo of cheap yet strong drinks. My kinda place. I don't even mind that its cash only.
author: Kendra P.

description: I don't know about this place.  I mean, it would appear to have the strappings of a place I would dig.  It really does have a good jukebox, and the jameson and fresh ginger is bomb.  They make a mean hot toddy too.  Plus you can smoke, which is always a nice addition as far as I'm concerned.  It's just....it's always too crowded with people who are trying too hard be cool.  I mean, it's a dive bar, not a fashion show.  That's just me though.  I'm not saying I wouldn't go back...I just wish the clientele weren't trying so hard.
author: Coco D.

description:
After standing in line  at another venue, for almost two hours to get into a show, only to have the door guy say that the bar has met it's capacity at the person in front of me and my friends, needless to say, we needed a drink - fast.
We trucked it back out to the Mission where one of my friends lives and decided to pop into the Phone Booth to throw down a few.
I ordered my usual Kettle and Cran, the husband got his usual whiskey sour, and our two friends ordered their usual Kettle and Tonic with a splash of Grapefruit juice (yeah - weird, I know!)
So, I watched as the bartender makes our drinks. In amazement, I see him literally pour almost half the bottle Kettle in our 3 vodka drinks. Then I saw him put a "splash" of cranberry in my glass, a splash of tonic and maybe a drop of grapefruit juice in the other two glasses. (I love this bar already!) Usually, I need to ask for a "splash of cran" in my usual and it's only really for the "color". But I didn't need to do that here. After a couple of these, I am feeling aaaaalllllrrrriiiiggggghhhhtttttt. The people at the bar were cool, drinks were good, and I seriously think we had a better time at the Phone Booth than if we made it in to see that show.
author: Jan Z.

description:
i haven't written about this place yet?
i have always stumbled home from this place, and sometimes it wasn't even my home. ummm...i mean... strong drinks! it gets rather crowded at times and i have been hit in the face with a pool cue here. accidentally, of course. luckily i was drunk, so it didn't hurt. they have deerhoof in the juke box.
author: Oleya P.

description: love this shit.  seriously awesome.  xo bitch-es
author: Pammy S.

description: You leave smelling like a pair of gym socks. It's kind of a shit hole. It's always packed with hipsters, good looking ladies, and plenty of people who get in photos with you and your friends, so the next day you go "who the fuck was that guy"  I love the place.
author: F B.

description: Me and my friend call it "The Haircut Bar".  It's pretty fun to go there and make fun of all the 80's revivalist haircuts and fake track bikes outside.  Hopefully you're trashed and ready to bounce before the novelty wears off.
author: SC ..

description: Another wonderful neighborhood dive and one I always bring out-of-towners too, usually after I've picked then up @ the airport.  Within' stumbling distance, usually a funky, socially adept crowd with whom a conversation with strangers over which Darren (from Bewitched) is better, and a dismally swank, yet perfect dcor makes this a fave.  2 caveats- Please get a short cue-stick for the pooltable AND...the occasional appearance of "stinky-tranny" can damper an otherwise good time.
author: Afab M.

description: I started going to the Phone Booth three years ago, largely because I had a major crush on one of the bartenders. fortunately, i quickly realized that the bar had more to offer than a cute hipster bartender. first, there were many other cute hipster boys (and girls, for those of you who go for that sort of thing). second, the jukebox is great. third, the drinks are ass-cheap, especially if you can find someone to split the jack and PBR special with you. it's my favorite bar, hands down, and i'm still going despite the fact that the cute bartender grew out his hair and became far less cute.
author: Casey P.

description:
fantastic jukebox, and the bar has creative drinks (i.e.,jameson and ginger juice) and classics.  hipster, laid-back and always a nice place to chillax and catch up with friends.

update: used to love this place, but these days it is a CLOUD OF CIGARETTE SMOKE.
author: Sid D.

description: A pool table, a jukebox with Xcellent options, fun bartenders (some), chill people, Xcellent cocktails, and a two blocks from home (and 24th street BART).  Truly a dive bar.  Their margaritas are very well made and have a popular ginger version.  plus, me can smoke.  Check out their barbie chandalier.
author: Adrian N.

description: I have a soft-spot in my heart (and probably in my gut) for the Phone Booth. The first time I went there, the power was out. No obnoxious music, no flashing lights - just friends, candles, and booze (strongest drinks in SF, period). Fantastic. More recent visits have meant some away time for the Phone Booth and I.
author: Blaine C.

description:
This is sort of the perfect bar for alcoholics.
You can drink here instead of drinking alone.

Tends to cater to lushes and theres always a group of gay companions.
The popcorn is always a favorite.
The liquor is relatively cheap.
author: Henry C.

description:
I spent about 4 nights here this past May. I am giving The Phonebooth 4 stars because it's definitely a go-with-friends place. Unfortunately if you're flying solo, I don't think this is the place to be. Additionally, you can smoke in the bar, which is fine with me, and I did- without realizing that I would smell absolutely like an ashtray and have to wash my hoodie twice to get the scent out. So just prepare yourself for those 2 things, and The Phonebooth will rock it for you.

On the upside, the drinks are fabulously huge and strong, and cheap! Pace yourself, because if you're usually a 3 or 4 drink type, you might want to have a little bit less and see how it's going. I don't know how they do it, but these are some stiff stiff drinks for a low low price, don't be fooled. The jukebox was great, the bartender was friendly, and the dim lighting only makes drunk goggles work even better.
author: Nick C.

description: YAY for whiskey with fresh ginger!! But be sure to specify 'fresh' because they also make the regular whiskey with ginger (as in ginger ale) here. Which, you know, is good and all but you can get that anywhere. Live it up! Go for the real stuff!
author: Angi C.

description:
so its my first day of third grade.
 
---my 3rd grade teacher-- "if anyone knows the answer to this(complicated) math question i will let you all go 5 minutes early for recess?"

---in my mind-- "i do its (some number, which i actually don't know)"

--my classmates in my imagination-- "yaaaaaaaaay... jeff rules" (as they carry me out on their shoulders, a hero.....a hero for all 3rd graders and the center of attention)



flash forward 19 years

--some guy at the bar (phone booth) -- "SOMEONE PLAY SOME TUNES" (slight lisp and drunkenly said)

--me in my imagination-- "i got it" as i throw a quarter in the general direction of the jukebox. it lands in the slot and i pick the perfect song. some song that everyone was waiting to hear

--my barmates in my imagination-- yaaaaaaaaaaaay jeff rules (somehow they know my name, and proceed to carry me out on their shoulders, singing and cheering for me.......a hero.......a hero for bar-people)


god I'm 27 and nothing has changed. 
and where are the people carrying me out on their shoulders?
and where are we going on their shoulders?
why are all my imagined situations the same. 
ill tell you one thing. 
next time someone does something sh older carrying worthy. they are getting a ride...........from me..........on my shoulders..........somewhere...
yaaaaaaaaaay jeff rules.


um as for the phone booth... ..... not sure yet. ....... lots of mustaches here.........( i mean don't get me wrong, i watched magnum PI marathons, and i consider Thomas magnum a far superior police/private investigator to TJ hooker or Remington Steele,  but the mustaches don't look good on you guys........only magnum. don't make him mad. you see what he did to Higgins (made him his bitch)) anyways......to be continued cause i've only been there once.
author: jeff e.

description: Wow it has been a long time since I've been to this place. It defenitely gets 5 stars from me if it's still the same. I remember it had a bitchin' juke box and really cheap beer. The best part was that I was able to smoke inside!!!! Oh, how I miss this place. I wish they could've moved with me.
author: Paul P.

description: Such a cozy little spot, it's like the Uptown, but smaller. I like when no smoking is happening, that's just me.
author: Colleen B.

description: Definitely chill, definitely found the $6 pbr and a shot of jack deal to be enticing, but also a horrible idea. Definitely dark in there. Definitely hard to find if you don't have directions. But nothing really definite about this place.
author: Ian S.

description: I really like this bar.  Its really laid-back and relaxed.  But be warned it is rather small and can get crowded.  I think I loved it mostly cause you could smoke inside.  Now that I don't smoke, having my clothes and hair reek of it is no longer appealing.  Nice drinks and a nice crowd.  Everytime I go there I make new friends.  Oh and there is a jukebox with a decent mix of music.  If I recall correctly I frequently played Michael Jackson and The Gorillaz.  But who knows, I was drunk and the music could have been in my head.
author: Isi C.

description: Saturdays at this place are the best. The bartenders are super on it and hilarious. The drinks are perfect. Popcorn and smoking?Wow. The music is eclectic..what can I say, Sold!
author: Chris S.

description:
i like to smoke and drink so this place is great. 
its dirty and like most dive bars smells like vomit and pee. 
but i love me a good dive bar.
author: Morgan G.

description: dive extravaganza. jukebox bliss, barbie light fixture, velvet wall coverings, even a lone spider spinning it's web over the toilet seat. does a bar get any better? it's a good place to drown ur worries or to float ur boat. the crowd is quite eclectic too. from the old man with a fedora stroking his knit scarf to the bubbly fat chick in fishnets sucking a red lolipop. all kinds.
author: S. G.

description: I kind of love getting the spot in the corner, and camping out until being there seems like a good idea. There's never a shortage of good people watching opportunites. I really like that it's small, I don't really like how smoky it gets.
author: katharine s.

description: damn, i'm the second reviewer!!  oh well... i was just missing this place so I thought I'd write a review.  I'm thinking of visiting tonight.  anyway, used to hang out here all the time with a good friend of mine (unfortunately she moved away  :(   )... chill, neighborhood type bar.  not too sceney if you go early...  good jukebox, stiff drinks and nice & dark.  just how i like it...  and right around the corner from la taqueria, my all-time favorite burrito joint!!
author: Yvette H.

description: I went to this bar in the Mission district at the behest of a friend, and was really pleasantly surprised.  The place looks super dive-y from the front.  Well, it is pretty dive-y inside too, but I stopped caring after I had a special drink that the bartender had invented, some pommegranate sake concoction served in a martini glass.  The martini and vodka collins I had subsequently were also ace, mixed strong and well.  The place boasts an amazing jukebox.  Also, they allow pets (not an issue for me, but I found it cute).
author: Stephen S.

description: The only problem is that they allow people to smoke in the bar, for non smokers this can be a problem. Your clothes will smell like an ash tray when you leave the place, to be honest this is the first place I've been in Ca where people can smoke inside, out in patios yes but not indoors.
author: Mauro B.

description: The Phone Booth is a great dive. It's a neighborhood bar for me and I love coming here to run into friends and listen to the jukebox. The bartenders are great and they make really stiff drinks!! You can smoke inside, which is a plus or a minus but I always make cool new friends here. The Phone Booth is a good place to have random interesting conversations and to wonder if the bartenders are gay or straight.....that's how you know if you have a good bartender on your hands, if you can't tell if  they are gay or straight.
author: Natalie H.

description: Actually it was ok the few times I've been here, plus you can smoke inside, which is kinda gross but whatever. I'm a social smoker so it works for me, but only if I'm kinda drunk as well (I'm just not used to smoking inside anymore, it weirds me out). It's been crowded all the times I've been here and it was hard to get a drink. But overall, not bad and the crowd is pretty fun and neighborhoody.
author: Gina R.

description: I like it here. But don't go here if you don't want to smell like smoke all night, that's my only complaint, and the jukebox that skips... and the weird bathrooms that the people playing pool can see into..but I mean other than that. yes.
author: Constance C.

description:
this is where TOPHER O'NASSIS was born!

small, super hipster, cheap drinks, they let you smoke inside...and...PBR!!!!

sometimes, the klassy van is right outside.
author: Ameigh F.

description: A good neighborhood spot in which non-regulars are accepted if they are friendly. Cheap strong drinks. Pool table. Good juke box. Smoking allowed inside (at night at least). Pretty friendly clientele and bartenders. It's the kind of place where you start chatting with the strangers sitting next to you.
author: Tim K.

description:
i didn't think this was a hipster bar at all (does that mean i'm a jaded super hipster?). it was packed and on the night we went there seemed to be two separate scenes going on inside it.  it seemed more of a ladies'-for-ladies pick-up joint to me.  my friend and i were getting cruised hardcore by different groups of women, but that was towards the back of the bar, the front was more hetero.

i liked it, our beers were $5 for two pints of stella and that's enough to make a girl weep. 

i'd like to check it out when it is less crowded.
author: ms.kiki g.

description: I feel a grudging love for this place.  Its kind of like an extension of my living room.  I feel no pressure to be friendly, impress anyone, or even have fun.  but I do, have fun at least, except when I forget that i'm not in my living room and get yelled at for lighting up something other than cigarrettes.  Whatever.
author: Emilia D.

description: Cheap, popcorn, and lots of lesbians with tatoos I'm afraid to compliment.
author: Paul K.

description: Good neighborhood bar for happy hour, but becomes less bearable as the nigh wears on.  Really good bartenders offering great pours and draft beers filled to the rim.  I guess I'm getting old or it's been too long since I quit (or both), but I have a hard time dealing with the smoke these days. I used to smoke in here and loved that you could, so it's all relative. Something for everyone on the jukebox
author: Jen S.

description: It's inexpensive, friendly, and has a great jukebox.  This is my go-to spot for drinks with friends.  I even went there last night.  I think I went there last weekend, too.  Damn, I go there a lot.
author: Chadwick W.

description: Appropriately named because it's very small.  However, there's a pool table, free popcorn machine, and cheap, strong drinks.  Surprisingly enough, a place this small actually has both a men's and women's bathroom; why they have see through glass on the doors, I don't know, but at least the stalls are private!  Overall, a great neighborhood bar in the Outer Mission.
author: Rick E.

description: One of my favorite bars in the neighborhood. It's just real comfortable. Good jukebox. Good clientele. Nice bartenders. Perfect.
author: Andrew L.

description: Very chill neighborhood spot. Friendly bartenders, generous pours, no pretension. One star for the chandelier alone, which is made with contorted plastic (barbie?) dolls. Only one star gone b/c you can smoke.
author: SL N.

description:
the phonebooth is MY bar! granted, i've lived on the same block as it for the past year and a half. really though, the booth was the first bar in san francisco i started going to on a regular basis. this place has so many amazing memories for me! i cant imagine never going in there (really! i'd go through withdrawals!). every time i'm there its a fucking party with good friends, cool bartenders, awesome music, and stiff drinks. honestly, what else can you for?


best part is? i can get obliterated and its only half a block home!
author: Jaei P.

description: Awesome jukebox, dive-y  with the double c's (casual and cool) atmosphere plus stiff drinks, full of locals and the bar tenders know how to make one of my favorite elixirs, captain morgan's w/ pineapple juice....shaken so it's nice and frothe......mornin'!!!!
author: erica u.

description: This is for the best jukebox in sf...at least so far.  fresh ginger drinks that make the mwind grow dim pickens.  2 dollar tecates.  also, you can play pool and the people who play are usually worse, so you can play for hours. sorry people who read this that a dude beat. also,  great bartenders.  a little too crowded for a maing on the weekends, but just far enough away from the main drag to be relaxing most times.
author: chreesh b.

description: yay for smoking in the bar. yay for a good jukebox. i put on 3 songs and i think everyone in the bar was enjoying them -- which is a good sign. drank a few anchor steams, had a few bogies, watched some pool. the bathrooms are a little weird, but whatever. overall, probably my favorite dive of the weekend.
author: Joanne S.

description:
dear phonebooth,
you never ever let me down! cheap delicious drinks that get me plastered every time (awesome bloody marys), i often bump into random friends from my past, but even if i don't, i never fail to make new friends. everyone, is nice, interactive, drunk. free popcorn, at least one of the same bartenders since i moved to sf around 2002, some things in the mission keep changing but i'm glad i can always come here at the end of my night and stumble out nearly nauseous!
author: celiac j.

description: A friend introduced my hubby and I to this bar when we were housesitting in Bernal Heights. I wish we had something like this in Berkeley (ha ha!) I would love it to be my neighborhood bar. Affordable drinks, friendly bartender, diverse crowd, I don't feel like it was overrun with hipsters at all - in fact that was a big part of the appeal... looking forward to going back!
author: Julia G.

description: Gotta love everything about this local dive bar except the smoking.... is what it is I guess.  Sometimes feel a little like I'm hopping in the water at fort point with a "heh is this a cool spot to surf" look on my face with the overly local feel, but great nonetheless.
author: Willy c.

description: jukebox bliss, barbie light fixture, velvet wall coverings, even a lone spider spinning it's web over the toilet seat. does a bar get any better? it's a good place to drown ur worries or to float ur boat. the crowd is quite eclectic too. from the old man with a fedora stroking his knit scarf to the bubbly fat chick in fishnets sucking a red lolipop. all kinds.
author: ray c.

description: Hipsters or not, these were some of the most friendly folk I've ever met at a bar, not counting Memphis in Santa Ana down south. My fear of being snubbed by pretentious regulars quickly disappeared after a cheery response from a pool table user. Everyone we ran into, literally and figuratively, was sincerely nice and interesting and, well, just chill; in fact, they were completely the opposite of pretentious. Perhaps the most snubbing seemed to have come from the bartenders, but I just blew it off as being busy and having to work New Year's Eve. Free champagne at midnight, cheap drinks--$17.50 for three, good long island iced teas. Maybe too good. Really too good. I felt very comfortable shoved in a little corner of the phone booth, playing partners pool all night with fantastic people we had just met. It's a bummer the BART stops running so early, it means next time I go I'll have to be outta there by midnight.
author: Kimberly C.

description:
phonebooth. i always thought of you as my neighborhood bar, i'm sorry that i didn't put in the effort to make our relationship come to fruition. now that i am moving to the east bay, i can only express my feelings through the lyrics of james blunt: 

Goodbye my lover.
Goodbye my friend.
You have been the one.
You have been the one for me.
author: Erica C.

description: if you like to dress up like you're straight out of napoleon dynamite, then throw your smoky clothes straight into the laundry basket when you get home, this bar is for you!  other than that it is actually pretty cool.
author: Alfredo I.

description: all my greatest friends love it here and it seems most yelpers do too.  i just can't bring myself to feel the same way and always get bummed when my group announces we'll be meeting here.  i think it's mostly that i don't smoke and end up inhaling about five cigarettes anyhow just being in the joint for a drink or two... and my clothes & hair will reek of smoke for the rest of the barhopping night. also it's almost always shoulder to shoulder with one bartender who can't hear your order over the yelling bar talk and music.     yeah the drinks are cheap and strong, fellow drinkers who smoke are happy as clams, and there's a fun mix of regulars but i just can't hang.
author: E M.

description: hipster hell , way too crowded, but the bloody marys there are worth their weight in gold
author: Lauren V.

description: What can I say, every time I go to phone booth I swear I will never go back. The place is OK until about 8pm when it gets super crowded and smoky. One thing I can say is that the drinks are strong and reasonably priced. But still its not worth it. The environment is hideous. The smoke is the worst part (sorry, cigarettes are foul when smoked in small enclosed areas). The bar itself is dingy. most of the people (uber hipsters)  stand around the pool table and play all night. Everyone else takes up the rest of the small bar, which inevitably is overfilled. The topics of conversation are .... well lets put it this way last time I was there I heard walmart mentioned three times. Once by a Humboldt native who now works as a techie in walmart's corporate office, once by a hipster who "just doesn't care what people say" walmart is her favorite store and and once by a tattooed messenger looking guy who was really excited that he was going to walmart with his friend the next day. Yeah, I don't think I really need to say more. I understand the appeal of this bar (and yes I go there every few months for an hour until I remember how much I hate it and swear I will never  return). I think it is just one of those places you either love or hate.
author: Emily S.

description: what can I say, I love this place yes it's a bit of a bummer being a non-smoker now, but the drinks are strong and cheap the music is usually good (depending on the people who put 10spots in the juke box) and the fact that it is still a neighborhood bar is nice-
author: A. Gun n.

description: if you like cigarettes (but i don't smoke) and margaritas (but i don't drink tequila), come here.
author: Lita F.

description:
After a lengthy, sweaty, 30 minute walk "over the river and through" the mothereffing woods from Hayes Valley, at least that's what it seemed like, my buddy and I finally roll into this place to meet up with an old friend.  All I wanted to do was sit the hell down, slide some suds down my throat and relax.  I accomplished approximately 1.5 of those goals.

My friend and her companion had a hook-up there with the bartenders, so we were stoked out on drinks all night and the service was top notch.  I can't complain on those two aspects, but then again it's tough to critique price and service when you've got a sly deal with the staff.  Unfortunately, they were fresh out of seats, so I got to stand all night long, which led to an annoyance which I hit on later.

The decor was a bit odd, although I was diggin' it.  If my memory serves me right, and often it doesn't (just a disclaimer), one of the main walls was red, and was adorned with Spanish-style bull fighting pictures.  As I ran my eyes past that wall, over to the pool table, and then back across the bar to the middle of the room where we were standing, my eyes stopped on a chandelier.  At first, I wasn't quite sure why I was even giving it more than a glance, but then I realized there were multi-racial barbies connecting the outer bulbs to the inner part of the fixture.  Uh-huh, yep, a barbie chandelier.  Just chillin', like it was a perfectly normal lighting fixture in any bar.  I don't know about you, Mr. and Mrs. Yelper, but I like when bars aren't afraid to throw random shit in their establishment.  It adds to the flavor and makes the place that much more of a trip as you start to get your drink on.  So there's that.

As for the crowd, it was quite the mix, which was nice.  Made for a fairly friendly atmosphere, because no group really had the upper hand numbers-wise.  The only thing that really pissed me off, was that the place ain't that big, and it was full of people (bad mix), so I was constantly, and I mean like 5-times-a-minute, getting bumped as people walked by.  There were no bad vibes or ill intentions, just passers by, but damn, that's a lot of spilled beer.  Luckily for me, mine was on the cheap.

Overall, not a bad bar to hit up.  It certainly doesn't get me all warm and fuzzy just thinking about it, but it serves pretty well for a dive.  My only advice is to get there early enough to get a seat.  Otherwise you're in for an expensive evening.
author: Travis F.

description: I always wondered why people liked this bar when I passed it.  After finally venturing in, now I see why.  The perfect mix of low lighting, cheap drinks, and no frills--exactly what I like in a bar.  And for peeping toms, there are two windowed doors looking straight into the girls bathroom...
author: Emma H.

description: my kind of place. dark. rock juke. pool table. cold cold stella drafts. it was all a blur. fantastic.
author: r b.

description: the phone booth rules because they have cheap strong drinks and they're really close to my house.  minus one star for awkward bathroom situation and for allowing smoking inside.  thanks for the extra cherries!
author: Charly G.

description: PBR on tap, Jim beam rye, a fucked up mix on the juke box (that's a good thing) old regulars by day, little hipsters by night, cool bar tenders.
author: elliot a.

description: If you ever have to send a dear friend to rehab, go here to unwind from the drama.  I did and it was fantastic.
author: pauline e.

description: yes, it's too smokey, which makes you feel gross the next day, even if you're a smoker. yes, the crowd has gotten so young that you begin to wonder whether you're the only one present with a valid i.d. but this is four stars just for the memories. because when i first moved here --- in the mid-90s, in my early 20s --- san francisco was feeling a bit dreary. the dot com thing was making yuppies out of 21-year-olds, the coolest kids were oversaturated in retro 60s culture, and i can't recall a single place where gays and straights hung out together and made out together and made memories together. maybe the 500 club? it seems like a stretch compared with what the phone booth was to become: The place to be, a place you squeezed into sloshy and dirty, knowing you'd leave in some sort of trouble. that was a couple years back now, and it's just become a neighborhood bar to me now, with a bit of melancholy attached --- considering what the place once represented. phone booth = friendster era. still, cheers to the fact that it exists. the owner is a sweetheart. and, hey, i think it's kind of fun to wonder whether the scruffy guy with the cheeky grin is gay or not, and to be truly unsure either way. he could be, after that next beer.
author: jeremy l.
